characters: WHO ARE YOU TO DECIDE IF YOU SHOULD
HOW CAN YOU BEGIN TO IMAGINE THAT
YOU THINK GOD ISN'T BIG ENOUGH TO
EARTH, THE SOURCE OF ALL LIFE, COULD
GOD, THE CREATOR OF HEAVEN AND

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FADE UP on ripples on the surface of a puddle.  Slow PAN UP:  the water becomes placid, and in it we see the reflection of an inverted CROSS on the top of a small church.  We move across the little churchyard and in through the open doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Utter simplicity -- stone walls, rough-hewn wooden benches, primitive saints in the stained-glass windows -- chickens peck among the straw that covers the earthen floor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little wooden grill slides open and the friendly face o the village PRIEST peers at us.  He glances about, perplexed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is anybody there? A small hand appears -- then the face of a girl aged abou 10, peering up at him through the grill.  The Priest smiles a trifle wearily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know I'm always happy to see you, Jeanne, but to keep coming here twice, three times a day...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to confess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you already confessed this morning...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to confess again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... alright.  What terrible sin have you committed since then that can't wait till tomorrow to be forgiven? Jeanne climbs up on the prayer-stool to be tall enough to look the Priest in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw a poor monk without shoes so I gave him some.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no sin in charity, Jeanne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They weren't my shoes.  Mine were too small.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose were they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sure he'll forgive you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He already did, but I want God to forgive me too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne -- if we were to ask forgiveness all the time, we'd spend our whole life in church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that bad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (perplexed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well no, but... Jeanne, are you happy at home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes... very.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And your mother -- everything's fine with her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes, she's... wonderful. FLASH:  we see Jeanne's peasant MOTHER, sitting by the fire, sewing.  Their home is little more than a hovel -- low, dark cave of a place, traversed by a huge beam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good, good.  And your sister... Catherine -- she's still your best friend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes, my sister's just... she's... wonderful. FLASH:  Jeanne's sister CATHERINE (18) sits near her mother, spinning wool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what about your other friends... you don't like playing with them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes, I play with them... lots... FLASH:  Jeanne is battling against some reeds with a wooden stick under a full noonday sun.  Not far away, a group of kids are in the shadow of a huge tree, playing. One of them watches Jeanne in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's she doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Playing. Resume on the Priest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... everything sounds... wonderful?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then... why are you here so often?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel safe here.  And it's where I can talk to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I try and talk to him, but mostly he's the one who does the talking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who is this "he"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He never says his name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What... does he... look like? FLASH:  a little boy of 8, sitting on a throne in a clearing in a wood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what does he say to you? FLASH:  the Boy points solemnly at us, but says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says... he says I must be good... and help everyone... and take care of myself.  Do you think he's coming from the sky?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps... but wherever he comes from, I think you should listen to him, because it sounds like he's giving you very good advice. The Priest smiles, and Jeanne beams back at him.  He blesses her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ego te absolvo, in nomine Patris, et Filii, et Spiritus Sancti, Amen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne runs from the little church, the weight of her sin now happily off her shoulders.  Her reflection skips across a little stream, then on through a meadow of cowslips and buttercups and up the sloping hillside beyond...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hazy, summer dusk -- pollen floating in the shimmering air... Jeanne swirls between the high elms, happy and carefree -- it's all a little surreal -- are those church bells in the distance?  Or cow bells?  Or merely the SOUN of insects? Jeanne swings round faster and faster, then tumbles over, laughing, and lies on her back.  She's dizzy and out of breath.  Above her, the clouds seeming to swirl as though she were still spinning round... The SOUND of the bells slows down, deepening... Her face moves into shadow.  Although not distinguishable as words at this stage, there's an urgent whisper in the wind... a strange echo that will eventually resolve into a call "Jeanne...!" Presently Jeanne turns and sees something glinting in the long grass.  A SWORD.  The background SOUND of the bells grows ominous.  A shooting star silently flashes across the sky -- then scores of them.  She gets to her feet and picks up the heavy sword.  It's growing darker -- colder -- the leaves have turned to autumn brown, now blown abou by a gust of wind. Presently she sees a WOLF approaching, slowly but straigh toward her -- then two, three -- finally the whole pack. She grips the sword, but can't use it -- too heavy, too frightened.  As the wolves approach, she closes her eyes... The wolves pass either side of her, as though oblivious t her presence.  When she opens her eyes, they have passed, and are now heading along the forest track.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne follows the wolves along the track.  They're heading toward a red glow, visible beyond the trees.  The wolves disappear over a ridge, though all we can see for the moment is the red sky beyond.  But as Jeanne reaches the edge, we move up with her to see... ... her village in the valley below, ablaze.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Panic -- screams -- crashing timbers -- animals stampedin -- wolves drag corpses from gutted buildings -- and through the midst of the tumult tears Jeanne, still dragging the sword she found.  She runs inside a farm cottage...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The low, dark building we saw earlier -- now empty, lit b the fires of the houses on the far side of the street. Jeanne runs in, searching about --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mother...? No response.  She begins to panic -- runs through into a smaller room beyond, calling out --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catherine?! Suddenly a door swings open and a hand reaches out -- Jeanne screams, then turns to see her elder sister, CATHERINE, who's been hiding in a cupboard...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne! Catherine embraces her, hugging her in relief --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you alright?  Did they hurt you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No no, I'm fine, really...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was so worried -- we've all been looking for you!  The English are everywhere!  O thank you, lord! She hugs her again -- then freezes, hearing the SOUND of horses, the clanking of armor.  But Jeanne hasn't heard..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was in church... Catherine glances about, ears tuned...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was talking to the priest, and do you know what he said to me? Catherine puts her hand across Jeanne's mouth --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shhh... tell me later... She hears the drunken laughter getting closer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quick -- hide in here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about me -- just stay in here... and don't move!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But where are you going to be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be right here... I promise. Catherine quickly lifts Jeanne inside the cupboard, locks the door, then turns to confront THREE hefty ruffians calling themselves soldiers.  The biggest and ugliest has a jet black beard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that's what I call booty! Blackbeard turns back to his comrades, who are sharing ou a roast chicken between them.  Catherine picks up the sword dropped by Jeanne as Blackbeard swaggers up to her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A woman with a sword? (to his comrades)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, take a look at this -- Frenchmen are such cowards that they've left all the fighting to women!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If that's God's will, then so be it! Blackbeard's comrades start tucking into their food, leaving Blackbeard to his pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine with me.  I love women. He undoes his buckle.  From her POV behind the cupboard door, Jeanne can just about see Blackbeard's face through a crack.  Catherine raises the heavy sword as Blackbeard advances, then brings it sweeping down.  But he intercept it effortlessly, grasping the blade as though it were a twig...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh... now you've hurt my feeling... He puts his hand around her throat, rips off her little wooden cross, pins her against the door, then, with a lecherous roar, plunges his face on her... Jeanne is terrified.  Blackbeard has his tunic down and i attempting to gain entry -- Catherine tries to scream -- he slams his hand over her mouth -- she bites it -- Blackbeard howls... with laughter.  Now his juices are really moving.  Catherine squirms against the door, twisting and turning --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hold still, bitch.  How can I do it if you keep wriggling about? He picks her up by the throat, lifts her clear off the floor by several inches, then rams the sword clean throug her gut and the door behind her, the blade just missing Jeanne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There, that's better. With a grin at his comrades, Blackbeard resumes his intercourse with the lifeless Catherine.  Behind the door Jeanne is suffocating with terror. The little wooden necklace lies on the floor in f.g. as Blackbeard pulls up his pants and turns to his comrades -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your turn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The little village church is no more than a smoldering pile of rubble -- among it, the twisted stained-glass of an angel.  Corpses are piled up alongside a warren of shallow graves, awaiting committal.  The Priest passes by each grave in turn, administering hasty last rites, then moving onto the next while a harassed grave-digger fills in the last. Jeanne stands by a shallow grave, now wearing her sister' wooden cross and grazing fixedly at her body, wrapped in linen and awaiting interment.  Her parents and other adults stand nearby, but at Jeanne's level we only see them from the waist down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We shouldn't be doing this by daylight... it's too dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right -- the English are still around -- I can smell them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When is the king going to do something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's good for nothing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... we can't even be sure he really is a king... (whispering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard someone say he's a bastard...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a mother like that?  I wouldn't be surprised... she's such a whore...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you show some respect?  We're burying our children.  You should be praying instead of cursing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's just about all we can do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... because only God can help us. Now the Priest scurries over, hurriedly mumbles the last rites in Latin, then moves on to the next grave.  Jeanne' family have their eyes closed in prayer, and it is only Jeanne who sees the Grave-digger nudge the corpse into th shallow grave with his foot.  He shovels in the earth, then moves on.  The Father puts his hand on her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Jeanne... your Uncle and Aunt are taking you to their house for a few weeks... just to give us time to rebuild what we can. Jeanne looks at him blankly, her thoughts too deep for tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne sits on the back of a small hay-wagon.  Her Uncle and Aunt are up front, eyes on the barren, devastated countryside ahead, while Jeanne gazes fixedly on the road behind.  From her POV:  the receding figures of her parents, gradually merging with the dusty landscape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large, low room, almost identical to Jeanne's house:  a bare, earthen floor with chickens running about, and a huge cave of a fireplace.  The Aunt doles out soup from a cauldron -- first to her husband, then to Jeanne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lord, we give thanks for the food you have given us.  Teach us always to love this land, and to save it from those who seek to destroy it. Amen. Jeanne says nothing -- noted by Daxart.  His wife nudges him with a gesture to let her be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daxart opens the door to an attic room, his wife standing behind him with Jeanne.  She wanders into the room, tidy but sparse, and sits on the edge of the bed.  Daxart look a little put out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... good night then. The Aunt understands Jeanne better than her husband, and leads him from the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Daxarts share the communal sleeping area with a coupl of goats and a mangy dog.  Daxart is settling down to sleep, but his wife lies awake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going to happen to her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll be fine.  She'll grow up... find a good man... make him some children.  Don't worry -- she's been hurt, but she'll survive.  Tomorrow she'll be as right as rain, you'll see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daxart opens the door to the attic.  Jeanne has not moved she's still sitting on the bed like the day before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to see a priest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christ, crucified in stained glass.  A silver cup is raised in blessing... The local PRIEST, much older than the one at Domremy, lowers the cup, filled with wine in preparation for the Mass.  The Daxarts enter the church at the far end, with Jeanne between them.  The Priest is expecting her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne sits in the shielded darkness of the confessional box.  She clutches at her little wooden cross and at last begins to cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard about your sister, and I... understand your pain...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did she have to die?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only God knows the answer to that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know Jesus says to love our enemies but I can't -- I just want the English to burn in hell for ever and ever!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I realize your anger, Jeanne, but we must learn to forgive.  It's hard, but revenge will never bring about peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then what will?  And what will bring her back?  And why did she have to die in the first place instead of me?  Why didn't he take my life instead of hers?  It was my fault -- I was late -- she gave me her hiding place...!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne... calm down...!  Calm down, Jeanne! Jeanne breaks off, trembling, tears pouring down her cheeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't pretend to know God's will, but I am sure of one thing -- the Lord always has a good reason. Perhaps he saved you because he needs you... for some higher calling.  So... as long as you answer that call, your sister will not have died in vain. Jeanne clams down.  She stares at the Priest for a long moment, and her look becomes very deep and intense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to wait for his call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne, be patient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to be with him always...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soon you'll be able to take the Holy Mass, and as you eat of his flesh and drink of his blood, you will be at one with him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to be at one with Him now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the open road, with Jeanne sitting on the back of Daxart's wagon.  It's a grey, lowering, dismal sort of day.  The Daxarts are up front, talking in low voices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He says we must bring her to church whenever she wants.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmmm... easy for him -- he's not the one that has to do the bringing. Behind them, the wagon is empty.  Jeanne is long gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rain pours down in torrents -- Jeanne runs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... down the deserted road -- into the church...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and up the aisle to the altar.  She grabs a jug of wine, pours some into the chalice -- holds it up high as the Priest did, then gulps it down.  The wine cascades from her mouth like blood as she gazes up at the stained glass image --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to be with you now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daxart sits bolt upright, awaking from a nightmare.  It's early morning, his wife still asleep beyond him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daxart opens the door to Jeanne's room.  Empty, the bed unslept in.  He walks in -- hears something.  Looking out of the window he sees -- Jeanne in the distance, playing be herself.  Daxart smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne pauses, her stick poised in mid-air --

dialogues.speaker: SUBLIMINAL FLASH --
dialogues.text: -- a real sword impales a soldier through the stomach -- another sword slices through chain-mail -- and a severed head encased in metal spins lose from armored shoulders..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne looks at Daxart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm playing. Once again Jeanne raises her stick-sword -- the head of a sunflower is violently decapitated --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and a sword swishes down, trying to hack someone in th leg.  But it is only a wooden sword, and its wielder a mere boy of five.  This is young Prince LOUIS, practicing his nascent swordsmanship on the castle GUARDS. VOICES and approaching footsteps alert the Guards, who quickly stand to attention as a door is swung open...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dauphin! Louis takes advantage of the Guards forced immobility, an jabs one of them in the leg... he lets out a muffled "Ow! The Dauphin CHARLES VII enters, followed by his courtiers They include the bloated REGNAULT, Archbishop of Rheims, and Georges de la TREMOILLE -- a sly and devious diplomat

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis, shouldn't you be learning your lessons?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to learn, I want to fight!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will, you will.  But for now, you must learn... at least to wipe your nose. Charles (who speaks with a slight stutter) affectionately wipes his son's nose with a corner of his shirt.  Beyond them, a young soldier, Jean d'AULON, arrives with a scroll.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A letter for His Majesty. Tremoille takes it, opens the seal and begins to read. Charles hands over Louis to a courtier...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another one from this girl calling herself the Maiden of Lorraine. Charles snatches it somewhat testily from Tremoille...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can read for myself, you know. While Charles reads, Tremoille turns aside to Regnault --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pretends she's been sent by God! These charlatans -- it's a pity there isn't enough wood to burn them all!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She says she'll be here tomorrow...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mustn't see her, my lord.  We know nothing about her... we don't even know if she is from Lorraine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What difference does it make where she comes from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If she comes from Burgundy it makes a difference.  It might be a trap... (takes back letter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look... Signed "X".  What sort of name is "X"?  Or must we conclude that a messenger of God can't even write her own name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lord Tremoille is correct.  She says she hears voices... she may be a sorceress... a witch...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snatching back letter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Regnault -- you see witches everywhere.  She's just a peasant... a peasant who cares for her king. Look... all she wants is to help me win my crown... and permission to fight for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not exactly. (takes back letter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wants you to give her an army -- at your expanse.  Bearing in mind that your mother stole every last piece of gold in the treasury, I fail to see how you can afford such an adventure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snatches back letter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can see her if I want to.  I mean, with half of France in the hands of the English, what have I got to lose?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other half.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mustn't see her, my lord.  She may be an instrument of the devil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... I think you should. All eyes turn to the window, where Yolande has been standing with her back to the room, reading a little book Her right-arm is standing beside her -- RICHMOND, his fac hideously disfigured by battle scars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Yolande... and what makes you think the exact opposite of my two most trusted advisors? Yolande smiles, though hardly a devoted smile.  Mild contempt would be more accurate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I care about you.  Come here. Charles walks over.  He has his shirt undone.  Yolande buttons it back up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your health and happiness has always been my first concern, Charles... ever since you were a little boy -- and I think I know you better than your own mother...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mmmm.  Yes.  I know for example the sickness that plagues your heart.  I know how painful it is for you... to have loved a father... without ever knowing if he really was yours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: W-w-what has that got to do with this Maiden?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who better than a messenger from God to give answers to your questions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really think she's been sent... by God?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a fine judge of character, Charles.  It'll take you less than five minutes to expose her if she's a fake.  But if she's not -- then she will give you your answers... and place the crown on your head. Charles shines at the prospect, but Tremoille and Regnaul look less than happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With respect, my lady, I think it's going to take more than just a simple peasant girl to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not interested in what you think, Tremoille -- or even what I think.  It's what simple people think that matters, and the fact is that simple people up and down the country are already talking about her.  Now you know what simple people are like, always ready to believe any old prophecy... like this one about a virgin from Lorraine saving France...? (hands Tremoille the book)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now this girl comes along -- from Lorraine -- and suddenly there's a spark of hope in their simple minds.  We shouldn't disappoint them.  If they believe in her -- if she can put back the fire in our army -- then I believe in her too.

dialogues.speaker: NIGHT
dialogues.text: Moving torches gallop toward us -- a FLAME flares through foreground with a whoosh, PANNING ROUND as soldiers ride toward the distant castle of Chinon -- a gloomy great silhouette, rising against a bloody sunset...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Celebrations after a hunt.  Troubadours play -- a whole tree trunk is burning in the vast chimney.  A Page comes running into the big room and hurries excitedly over to Charles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's coming, your majesty... with an armed escort!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, alright -- calm yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your majesty, I urge you not to see this woman.  It all reeks of a Burgundian trap!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My astrologers assure me that the hour is p-p-propitious -- Leo, with Virgo rising.  Have you ever noticed on the astrological chart how the Virgin is next to the Lion?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Supposing she's an assassin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tremoille, I'm not even king yet... who'd want to assassinate me? Looking around at his courtiers?  They all would.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A FLAME swirls in the darkness -- the urgent clatter of horses hooves -- steaming breath in the cold night air -- the SOUND of festivities coming from the castle walls beyond -- the horses are reined -- one whinnies as SOLDIERS jump down onto the cobbles -- a dark cape wraps about a figure...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another page boy bursts in --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's arrived, my lord!  She's in the guards' room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... I suppose I'd better make a decision. Charles glances between Tremoille, Regnault and Yolande, but -- either by accident of will -- none are looking his way.  He sighs deeply to the dashing, open-faced young soldier we saw earlier, Jean d'AULON...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh dear, why is life so complicated? Sometimes I really wish I could be someone else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's a good idea, sire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let someone else pretend to be you, and see if...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... if she can find me? -- That's a brilliant idea!  If she's really been sent by God she'll discover the trap, and if she's an assassin she'll kill the wrong man! (to the page)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring her up! Charles turns to a coterie of ARMY CAPTAINS, standing aside and aloof from the courtiers whom they evidently despise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear Captains, I've had a brilliant idea!  We're going to have a little game.  Now... let's pretend my throne is empty.  Who wants to be the king? They all put up their hands...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now there's a heart-warming sight! So let's see... which one of you could possibly pass as king? He turns to the Duke of ALENCON, 25, strikingly handsome in his bright, gilded armor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Alencon, my noble duke, my royal cousin -- so fine, so brave, so rich -- so very rich -- so far-too-rich to be the King of France.  Everyone knows I'm the poorest man in my kingdom. He turns to GILLES de Rais:  a dark, glamorous seducer, dressed in black armor with a ring through one ear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gilles de Rais... Marshal of France... formidable to men, fascinating to women, feared by all. You'd be perfect to sit on my throne... so perfect that you might like it too much for my own piece of mind. Charles turns to the bearded La Hire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, La Hire -- my angry captain... the bravest in France -- scarred by a dozen wars, but with heart and stomach for a dozen more.  You could pass for the king...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn bloody right I could!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... until you opened your mouth.  No one with a tongue like yours could pass as the King of France. The other Captains laugh heartily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah well... it looks as though it's going to have to be me after all... But... wait a minute... Charles spots the shy Jean d'Aulon.  Unlike the other court toadies, Aulon is a quiet, honorable man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not you -- Jean d'Aulon?  The only man who's poorer than I am, and so the only man I can trust. Dignified, honorable, wise... what more could we ask of a king?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lord, I'm not sure that... Charles takes his coat and puts it around Aulon's shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear Aulon, to you it shall befall the honor of impersonating the royal blood!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Majesty, I can't...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, are you not ready to die for your king?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I am, it's just that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  Until then, feel free to live like a king! Laughter -- then the sound of approaching excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry, hurry -- on the throne...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Armored feet clank along a stone corridor --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles unceremoniously dumps Aulon on the throne...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sire, you know how bad I am at this sort of game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... pretend it's not a game. Charles abandons Aulon and disappears among his courtiers A pair of PAGE BOYS swing open the doors:  the courtiers turn expectantly; Aulon tries to pose as the king. From the Court's POV, a girl of 17 enters the great hall, dressed in a grubby tunic, with long hair tied back beneath a hood.  There could not be a more striking contrast than the sophisticated, opulent, yet cowardly courtiers and this naive, rough girl, almost childlike in her simplicity, and yet so focused, so confident, so secure in her mission, with a courage that radiates conviction, and is contagious. The courtiers step back to form a narrow channel as she moves into the great hall.  Yolande marks the effect her presence has on the court, smiling at their bemused gazes Jeanne passes the Archbishop, who defends himself by sprinkling holy water in her path.  Tremoille oils his wa toward her with a can-I-help ingratiating smile...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have come to see the Dauphin. Tremoille nods obsequiously, ushering her toward Aulon, who is now visibly uneasy.  Jeanne stops in front of him. Aulon gazes at her.  Jeanne scans him a couple of times, looks at him stonily.  Then smiles.  Aulon melts, his cheeks blushing hot.  Jeanne cocks her head, like an inquisitive child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you? Aulon stammers in response...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... His most gracious majesty Charles de Valois, Dauphin of France... She gives Aulon another smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can see you are a good man, but you're not the Dauphin. (to Tremoille)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to insist, but we have no time to lose.  I must see the Dauphin.  Where is he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's here. (a gracious gesture)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Find him yourself. A brief pause, then Jeanne takes up the challenge.  She moves on, examining the faces acutely.  Although a few of the wimpoled ladies find her simple peasant dress amusing most are caught like moths in her flame.  She notices the Three Captains (La Hire, Alencon and Gilles de Rais) edging closer together, as though shielding someone beyond. Jeanne approaches them -- they draw closer together, but now we can see Charles, overtly curious, yet anxious to remain hidden.  His inquisitiveness wins -- but as Jeanne walks up to him, the Three Captains spring in front of her, swords drawn, the tips pressing at her throat...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no need to be afraid, sire.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm... I'm not the king...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know you're not yet -- but you will be, soon. Charles makes a gesture, and the soldiers cautiously sheath their swords.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: H-h-how did you know who I am?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her voices, of course...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "That's him" they said, "The one with the big nose and bags under his eyes." They laugh -- whereupon Jeanne rushes at Charles and flings herself on her knees, embracing him round the ankles. Charles screams -- the 3 Captains redraw their swords -- the court gasps -- then Charles gestures the Captains to back off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My gentle Dauphin, I bring you good news. Charles puts out his hand to her, allowing her to rise. She draws close to him, whispering...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is a message from the King of Heaven.  For you -- and you only. Jeanne speaks with such conviction that it seems unnecessary to doubt her.  Her mesmeric effect on Charles is being noticed by his courtiers.  He hesitates a moment then --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Follow me. He leads her from the room.  Tremoille hurriedly follows them.  Charles turns round in the doorway, barring him further access.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your majesty, I really think you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear loyal Tremoille, I know I can count on you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... as always, majesty...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... to ensure our privacy.  I need to talk to her.  Alone. Tremoille looks non-plussed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you wish, majesty. Charles disappears with Jeanne. Tremoille ire at being barred is mollified by blocking th path of Yolande.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He needs to talk to her.  Alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne is seated facing Charles in front of a huge fire. As the scene unfolds, their faces draw closer and closer. Her voice is soft and sweet, but her conviction is absolute.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was about eight years old.  It was a beautiful spring day.  I was in the forest taking a short cut home when the wind started blowing in the trees -- such a strange sound -- almost like words -- as if someone was calling... FLASH:  The little BOY seen earlier is seated on his chai in the middle of the field, pointing his finger at us --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles is intrigued...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The second time was many years later.  It was autumn, and I was coming back from church when suddenly the same violent wind started to blow again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLASH:  The wind lifts Jeanne (17) from the ground, spins her forward and flattens her on her back, her arms outstretched, Her face gazing upward at the sky...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything was moving so fast -- the wind -- the clouds -- I couldn't move!  Then suddenly a shape appeared in the middle of the sky... The fast-moving CLOUDS resolve themselves into the shape of a face... the face of an OLD MAN.  He opens his mouth wide, radiating a shaft of sunlight that strikes Jeanne, still lying in the field.  The old man's mouth seems to form the word "Jeanne", but the sound that emanates is so vast that we can't be sure. Suddenly the mouth snaps shut, releasing a huge FLASH OF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Charles jumps back, startled yet totally absorbed. Jeanne's eyes sparkle with tears --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was so frightened... he was so -- so here... FLASH:  The Boy is still sitting in his forest seat, but now he is a beautiful young Man, pointing his finger at Jeanne --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I realized then that he had chosen me, but I didn't understand what it was I had to do... Jeanne's eyes sparkle with intensity...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was my mission?  To help my country?  But how could I do that? I was only a poor girl who knew nothing about riding or making war... so I decided to wait and not to speak to anyone about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You did well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't wait long.  One day I was going to Mass, like I do every day, when the same strange wind started blowing again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The double doors of a church are blown open by wind comin from inside -- right in front of Jeanne!  Surreal shafts of light criss-cross the interior from the stained-glass windows, illuminating Jeanne in myriad hues and colors. She sways uneasily as the central stained-glass window above the altar starts to warp and undulate, like heat waves creating a mirage.  The image of a beautiful archangel slowly comes to life, stepping out from the window frame, then moving toward Jeanne...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything was suddenly made clear to me.  God was finally calling me. He had a mission for me -- a message to deliver... The Archangel opens his arms to Jeanne as though to embrace her.  She drops to her knees, opening her arms an

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles is in suspense, his face sweating...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and what... what did he say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said that I have to save France from her enemies and give her back to God, and He told me that I -- Jeanne -- will lead you to the altar at Rheims to be crowned King of France. Charles slowly releases the breath he's been holding -- and the brimming tears run down his cheeks.  Jeanne takes his hand and places it on her own damp cheek...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All you have to do now is put your trust in me. Jeanne kisses his hands, and Charles is almost overcome with emotion.  He seems, for the first time, utterly defenseless, like the little hurt boy that he is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I trust you, Jeanne -- I do -- and I envy your certainty, but how can I be certain that I have the right to call myself king when I don't even know who my father is.  My mother can't even remember... I -- I need to know... Jeanne gazes at him a moment, then places her hands eithe side of his head and draws him slowly forward until both their foreheads are touching...

dialogues.speaker: FLASHES
dialogues.text: A series of too-perfect images: 1:  A BELL comes crashing down on top of us -- 2:  The ROYAL BANNER flies triumphantly in the wind -- 3:  English CAPTAINS throw down their weapons and kneel i submission before Charles -- 4:  Huge city GATES swing open, releasing a jubilant crow who welcome the King in triumph -- 5:  CHARLES kneels in Rheims Cathedral -- 6:  Bejeweled HANDS place the CROWN of France on his head --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne's hands hold Charles' head, as though she has just crowned him.  For Charles, the fantasy has become reality

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you really believe that God would let all this happen... if you were not the true King of France?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Courtiers talk among themselves, nervously awaiting Charles to rejoin them.  Presently the door opens and Charles emerges, followed by Jeanne.  He is a man transfigured.  Tremoille looks anxious.  Charles glances at them, their expectant eyes awaiting his verdict.  He leads Jeanne across to Aulon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne, this is -- in fact -- my loyal friend and finest archer, Jean d'Aulon.  Jean... I place her in your care.  Find her suitable lodgings -- here -- in the castle... and guard her with your life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't need lodgings if we're to be marching on Orleans...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orleans has held out for six months. I don't suppose a few days will make much difference.  Take some rest. Jeanne follows Jean d'Aulon from the Great Hall, watched in silence by his courtiers.  As soon as she's gone, the whole room is filled with the myriad buzz of opinion. Gilles gives Charles the eye...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She certainly cast a spell on you. Charles draws his three Captains aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll cast her spell on everyone if she's given half a chance... and we must ensure that she gets that chance. The Captains look astonished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you imagine the effect it will have on the English -- to see a girl riding at the head of our army?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  They'll bleeding wet themselves!  Laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're not your favorite captains anymore??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No -- I mean yes! -- of course...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles... you want to give the command of our army to a -- woman??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not!  You're the ones in command, as always... but if she can put back the fire in our soldiers, then maybe you, my dear Captains, will be able to raise the siege of Orleans.  What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brilliant idea... but to be really effective, why not send a whole army of virgins?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That'll put fire in my soldiers! The Captains laugh -- at Charles' expense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, my friends... you know me... you know how certain I am about everything, but -- maybe for the first time in my life I -- I don't know why -- but I feel I have to trust her... and now I'm asking you -- I'm begging you -- to trust me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne blows the dust from a wooden crucifix, then replaces it above a bed.  Jean d'Aulon has brought her to a small room in one of the castle's turrets:  clean, plainly furnished, but hardly hospitable.  Jeanne inspect the room while Aulon stands by the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, please accept my apologies for... you know, me pretending to be the... well it wasn't really my idea... well, yes it was my idea but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think I could have some water? Jeanne smiles sweetly, catching Aulon off guard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, of course... water... anything else? Two page boys run into the room, carrying luggage, water, washing bowl and some food.  They are LOUIS and RAYMOND, both 13, as inseparable as they are loyal.  Jeanne looks up, then sits on the bed, testing the horsehair mattress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would like some fresh straw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louis... water and fresh straw! Louis goes running off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I would like to see a priest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  I didn't confess today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. (to Raymond)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raymond... a priest. Raymond goes running off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shall also be needing a war horse -- mine is too slow -- and armor -- and a good sword -- and an artist to make me a banner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better today than tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... uh -- this might take a little time -- but let me see what I can do. He's about to leave when Jeanne adds --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I also need someone who can read and write.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This I can do. (Jeanne looks surprised)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was studying at the University of Paris -- till the English invaded it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you were an archer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I am.  I'm an archer who can read and write.  Who do you want to write to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The King of England.  I want to give them the chance to leave Orleans in peace before I get there. Aulon just stares at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raymond hands a rolled parchment to a Rider, already mounted and waiting...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rider gallops over the drawbridge and away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tremoille stands on a terrace before Chinon, watching the rider heading down the dusty highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe you let her send such a letter... Charles is a short distance away, watching Jeanne in a meadow below the castle, swishing a stick from side to side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's going to do it. Tremoille exchanges a worried glance with Archbishop Regnault, who is standing behind Charles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sire, it's going to take more than a letter to drive out the English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An army for instance...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My captains have sworn their support.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No doubt your captains will fight for your fine cause -- but what about the ordinary soldier?  They don't fight for causes these days. They fight for money.  Who's going to pay them?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am. Yolande moves forward, accompanied by her daughter Mary (Charles' wife) and grandson, young Louis.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For the sake of France, Charles. And for the sake of my grandson. She pats Louis on the head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With respect, my lady -- the Archbishop and I have begun delicate negotiations with the Burgundians. If we can bring them over to our side...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Negotiate by all means, but from a position of strength.  If the English take Orleans, there'll be nothing left to negotiate -- the rest of the country will be theirs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lady, it would be the height of folly to let this... child... lead our army in the king's name without first verifying her true motives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tremoille is right.  This girl must be subjected to a rigorous examination by the Doctors of the Church at Poitiers.  We need to be absolutely certain that she is not an instrument of the devil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can anyone be absolutely certain about anything?  Our intuitions are sometimes our best counselors...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must listen to Mother Holy Church before listening to our intuitions.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait... she claims to be a virgin... Well that's something we can examine -- and be absolutely certain about. Charles hesitates -- turns to Yolande, who looks somewhat uneasy at the suggestion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? Charles looks across to Jeanne in the distance, still playing with her stick.  Suddenly she swipes at a bulrush violently decapitating its head.  Charles looks worried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's find out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A big, spacious room, into which files a procession of TE DOCTORS of THEOLOGY and TEN NOTABLES, walking two-by-two. They divide either side of CAMERA, then halt and about- turn, facing inward with military precision.  Two PAGE BOYS set up screens in front of the two rows, preventing them from viewing Jeanne, who is standing on a low table between the rows, wearing a laced-up robe. Now a procession of NUNS form up behind the table.  Two o them step forward, on cue, then proceed to loosen the laces of Jeanne's robe and roll up the hem.  Meanwhile an old HAG is washing her hands. With Jeanne suitably prepared, the old HAG stands in fron of her.  Two little Girls slip in a special stool and the old HAG squats down, enabling her to look between Jeanne' legs.  Only women are privy to this ritualistic inspection; the men remain standing behind the screens. Yolande waits with the disfigured Richmond near a window. The old Hag is certainly taking her time, and Yolande is getting decidedly nervous...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if she's not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll kill her myself... A few tense moments -- then the ancient HAG announces wit great solemnity...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no sign of corruption or violation.  She is intact. ... to Yolande's visible relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dark, musty council room, where theologians and learned doctors of the Church sit in wooden tiers, examining Jeanne.  Archbishop Regnault is among them.  So too is Jean d'Aulon -- but he as a silent, albeit supportive observer. Jeanne stands in the center of the room, hands folded, as though on trial.  She's evidently been here many hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And... what exactly was this -- "vision" -- wearing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't remember.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was it wearing a crown?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I saw no crown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, was it naked? The Court have a good chuckle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think that God can't afford to give him clothes? An audible reaction, somewhere between amusement and admiration.  A deadpan scribe carefully writes down both questions and answers in a large, vellum-bound book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did this -- vision -- give you anything -- an object, like a ring, or a rosary or anything -- by which we can verify your claim?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gave me good advice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During your childhood, did you have any sort of military experience?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you practiced in the skills of swordsmanship?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  But I'm good with a stick. A murmur of laughter, though not from us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know what a Dijon Culverin is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an item of artillery.  How do you expect to raise the siege of Orleans if you are ignorant about modern artillery?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The road to Orleans is long, and I have good captains with me.  I will learn fast, believe me. The Inquisitor and his colleagues whisper in a huddle. Regnault remains unconvinced, and indicates his strong reservations.  Finally the Chief Inquisitor addresses Jeanne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We would like to believe you Jeanne, but we feel that if God were to want us to believe in you, he would have sent you with a sign as proof that we should believe in you.  We cannot advise the King to entrust you with the army merely on your assertion. Can't you do something?  Or show us something?  Some sign to prove that you are sent by God?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sire, I did not come here to preform tricks.  You are all much cleverer than I am -- me, I don't know A from B -- but this much I do know:  that while the people of France lie bleeding, you sit around in your fine clothes trying to deceive me -- yet all you're doing is deceiving yourselves.  You say you are men of God, yet you can't see His hand in having guided me safely through five hundred leagues of enemy country to bring you His help?  Is that not proof enough?  Or do you want still more signs?  Give me command of an army, take me to Orleans, and there you will see the sign I was sent to make! Aulon can barely restrain himself from applauding.  The Chief Inquisitor reaches his decision, raises his gavel and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- down comes a mallet, SLAMMING out a safety wedge which releases a CATAPULT -- and a huge boulder flies across th river in the direction of Orleans...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A LOOK-OUT spots the incoming missile -- yells out --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 45-er, nor-nor-west -- straight at us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DUNOIS is alone, writing a letter at a small table --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which side's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Window side...!! Dunois realizes he's near the window and dives for cover just as the massive boulder plummets through the ceiling, demolishing the table where he'd been sitting seconds before, and leaving a huge hole in the wall. Dunois emerges from under a large table, dusting himself. He looks thin, haggard and exhausted after six months of siege. Suddenly a young soldier -- Poton de XAINTRAILLES -- come bursting in, ignoring the mess...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lord Dunois... I have wonderful news! -- finally -- he's sending her to us -- thanks be to God -- we're saved -- it's wonderful!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calm yourself, Xaintrailles.  Now slowly.  Who has finally done what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dauphin -- he's sending us food -- and supplies -- and an army -- led by Jeanne -- the maiden from Lorraine -- isn't it wonderful?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (deadpan)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it's a miracle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it's not the first one!  They say she saved a little boy who was dying of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Xaintrailles...!  Don't talk to me about miracles... (pointing to hole in floor)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I was still sitting there waiting for a miracle, I'd be dead now. Anyway... Dunois looks up at the sky, now visible through a hole in the roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But... don't you think we should at least... go and... welcome her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sighs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As long as she brings food and supplies, she'll be welcome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The walled city of Orleans stands in the distance on the far side of the river Loire.  CAMERA CRANES DOWN to find Dunois, Xaintrailles and a small escort of soldiers, waiting atop a ridge where they're evidently been for som time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe they're sending a woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe they never sent anyone. TRAVELING SHOT:  Horse's hooves galloping...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder what color dress she'll be wearing? TRAVELING SHOT:  Horse's breath steaming...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll wager red -- how about you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blue... TRAVELING SHOT:  Stirrups press into the horse's flanks..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... with a blue ribbon in her hair to tie up Talbot! TRAVELING SHOT:  the horse's eyes, wild and dilated...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does anyone know if she even knows how to ride a horse? TRAVELING SHOT:  horse's legs at the triple gallop...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She knows... THEIR POV:  a white banner sweeps into SHOT -- then a knight clad in shinning white armor.  The knight raises his visor to reveal -- Jeanne, her face gleaming with sweat, eyes blazing.  Dunois is speechless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you sent by Lord Dunois?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... they were.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  Where are the English?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everywhere.  Where is the food?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's coming -- I rode on ahead.  I have to speak with the Captain of the English army... his name's Talbot...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  Can you bring me to him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's on the other side of the river. Now La Hire and Gilles de Rais ride into view...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So who gave the order to bring me to this side of the river??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling to Dunois)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, my friend!  I'm glad to see your ugly damn face again!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: La Hire, I'm warning you -- don't swear!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry Jeanne... (to Dunois)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you both meet already?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... sort of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Dunois, smiling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's quite something, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne, let me introduce the king's half brother, the dogged Lord Dunois.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, Lord Dunois, show me the way to the other side of the river... She starts to move as Jean d'Aulon rides up --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, wait...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because... because -- I mean -- the English have a broad sense of humor, but... I mean, you don't understand... to them you're a witch, working for the devil.  What makes you think they'll listen to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because if they don't, I'll raise such a war-cry against them that they will remember us forever!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well.  I'd love to see that, but after taking counsel with my captains, I felt it would be better to first bring the food into the city, then wait till Alencon arrives with reinforcements before doing anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You may have been with your counsel, but I've been with mine, and I'm telling you, God's counsel is wiser than yours, and he's telling me to speak to the English -- now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (matching her anger)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine -- go now if you want, but not with me!  You may have a duty to God but I have a duty to my people, and my people are starving!  So right now I'm going to take the food back to the city, and if you can please calm down, and let me accompany you to Orleans, it will be my honor to welcome you. Gilles smiles at Jeanne's evident frustration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The battered east gate of Orleans swings open, and a convoy of wagons enter the town, guarded by soldiers. Jeanne and the Captains are on horseback, the remainder o foot. A group of hungry children spot the arrival, their eyes widening at the sight of the food:  beef, mutton, chickens, sacks of grain, barrels of salted fish... But most of the citizens are too starved and too weary to show much excitement; hollow-eyed and emaciated, they hav the expressionless faces of concentration camp inmates. La Hire is sickened at the sight...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ... the goddamn English will pay for this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They will -- and so will you if you go on swearing like that. By the time the little procession has reached the main square, a CROWD has gathered.  Sluggishly they make way for Jeanne and Dunois to ride between them... Now the interest in Jeanne begins to warm up -- the CROWD press in on her.  Slowly at first, but with increasing fervor, the pressure builds as the crowd  try to touch her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bless us, Jeanne...!  Save us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soldiers push back the crowd, allowing Jeanne to reach a large gabled house.  As she dismounts, a woman runs forward --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne!  Bless her -- touch her! The woman holds up her BABY for Jeanne to touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Touch her yourself... your touch is just as good as mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But... you've been sent by God!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So has everyone. Jeanne turns sharply away and walks inside the house, followed by Aulon and the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A frustrated Jeanne marches into Dunois' new war-room. Dunois enters, followed by his Captains, and is happy to see a model of Orleans...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: La Hire, Gilles -- let me show you something... The Captains go into a huddle, leaving Jeanne smarting. She looks out of the window, where the crowd is still trying to catch a glimpse of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who do they think I am?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne, calm down.  You can't blame the people -- they've been hearing all about you for weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing to hear -- I haven't done anything.  And why haven't I done anything? (turning to the captains)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because none of you will listen to me!! She shouts in frustration, and Dunois and the other captains swing round.  Dunois waits for the echo to die away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you like to join us?  We're about to discuss the campaign... Jeanne walks over, still vexed.  Using the model, Dunois continues his situation briefing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From here, Talbot has spread his forces between these forts up here, but in the last few days it seems -- according to our scouts -- that some troops have been deployed to this fort here -- which makes me think that this is where they'll be launching their attack from... Dunois points to St. Loup -- a smaller fort to the east.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would have thought they'd have attacked from here, where Talbot is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I doubt it.  From here they won't be able to utilize the river, whereas over here the current will be with them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about this huge pile down here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the Tourelles.  The English were planning to launch an attack from it, but then we broke down the bridge, which should keep them quiet for a while.  My hunch is, the attack will come from St. Loup. He pauses, then turns to Jeanne, somewhat apprehensively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And... what does Jeanne think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think.  I leave that to God. I'm nothing in all this, I'm just the messenger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... what is the message?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We offer the English a last chance to return home in peace.  If they refuse, we recross the river and attack them here -- at the Tourelles. They all look astonished.  Gilles grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne, that really makes no sense at all.  The Tourelles is virtually impregnable... besides, if we're on the other side of the river attacking the Tourelles, what's to stop Talbot attacking the city from the north?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God... why of course -- we'd forgotten about him!  Strange, I don't seem to remember seeing him at Agincourt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Damn right!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, but I forgot!  It was a Sunday... that explains it.  God's day off. They all laugh, apart from Aulon and the page boys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I feel a great sorrow for you, because you're laughing now, but by tomorrow night some of you will be dead and having to repeat your jokes in front of God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne, with respect -- we can't just attack the Tourelles like that -- it's a very complicated matter and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What complicated about it?  All you have to do is do what you're told -- what could be simpler than that? I'm the drum on which God is beating out his message -- beating so loudly it's bursting my ears -- but you're all so full of your own voices, you're deaf to His!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne, be patient... Jeanne turns on him --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Be patient, be patient"... is that the only advice you can ever come up with??  I've shown more patience than a dozen saints!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne, you have to understand -- it's not easy for us -- I mean for our pride -- to suddenly be usurped by a -- well, with all due respect, by a... girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, so that's it.  To you I'm just a girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne, put yourself in my shoes for a moment -- how would you feel, if you were me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Knowing what I know?  Enormous gratitude. Jeanne turns and heads for the door.  La Hire nudges Gilles as she approaches --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One hell of a girl, huh? As she passes, Jeanne slaps La Hire right across the face --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I warned you! -- and walk out, slamming the door behind her.  The other stare after her, while La Hire nurses his cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to La Hire)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do love her when her fire gets well and truly stoked!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too... A pause, then the door at the other end of the room burst open and in walks the expansive Duke of Alencon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello my friends!  What a journey, but we made it!  Back together again... let's have some fun! He rubs his hands in anticipation, then notes his comrades' expressions, still recovering from Jeanne's outburst.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I miss something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne draws her sword with a terrifying scrape as though about to kill someone, slices something in f.g. -- and a chunk of black hair falls to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what if I'm a girl...? (cuts another chunk)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You need to look like a man to drive out the English? (and another)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine... let's look like a man! Aulon grabs her by the wrist to take the sword from her -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne, stop it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How dare you stop me doing God's will! Aulon wrestles to get the sword from her --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He didn't tell you to cut all your hair off...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How dare you tell me what God tells me to do!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, whatever -- but since He's not going to come down and cut it himself, at least let someone cut it properly! He finally manages to grab the sword from her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raymond -- bring me scissors! Louis -- fetch that mirror! The two page boys hop to it, but when Louis brings the mirror, Jeanne slaps it from his hand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne, stop getting so angry about everything...!  Calm down! Jeanne stares at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am calm.  It's God who's angry.  I need to send a letter.  Now. Aulon looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dunois reads the parchment that Aulon hands to him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To you, Henry King of England, and to you, Duke of Bedford who call yourself Regent of France, obey the King of Heaven and abandon your siege... Dunois can scarcely believe it.  He hands it to Alencon..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... give back the keys to the other towns you have taken, and go back home to your island... Equally bemused, Alencon hands it to La Hire...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To you Lord Talbot, I beg you as humbly as I can beg you, for the sake of the lives of your soldiers, do not bring about your own destruction... La Hire whistles with admiration and hands it to Gilles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Surrender to me, Jeanne the Maiden, who is sent here by God, and she will make peace with you... Gilles grins, and hands back to Aulon, who looks to Dunoi for an answer.  Dunois gives a vague nod of the head...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jeanne's letter continues, Aulon walks across the broken stone bridge that once connected the city to the south bank of the Loire.  Two-thirds the way across, the bridge ends abruptly, leaving a yawning gap between us an the fortress of the Tourelles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... but if you do not heed my warning, then we shall raise such a battle-cry as there has not been heard in France for a thousand years!    Aulon takes the arrow to which Jeanne's letter is already tied, places it in the bow -- takes aim and fires...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The arrow lands in wooden planking.  An English soldier with a flaming red beard yanks it out, gives it a cursory glance, grins, then clambers down to the courtyard below where soldiers are busily trimming the branches from freshly-felled trees.  Redbeard hands the letter to an English captain, Glasdale...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the third and last time I will write to you... Glasdale reads it, and gives his response.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aulon is still waiting at the end of the broken bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you are still here at noon, I warn you that you will hear from me to your very great destruction. Please give me your answer speedily. Redbeard yells out from the top of the Tourelles...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go fuck yourself!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aulon hesitates, then softly opens the door.  He tiptoes into the room, looks at Jeanne, then at Louis, who has fallen asleep with the scissors still clasped somewhat dangerously to his chest.  Aulon gently removes them.  As he places them on the table, Jeanne murmurs in her sleep, but without opening her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did they say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... they said... they will think about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But... to be honest... I don't think they'll leave tomorrow. Jeanne is almost asleep again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't wait... for tomorrow... Aulon sits in a chair nearby, gazing at Jeanne, who now looks even younger, with her hair shorn short like a boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SMASH CUT into the fury of battle -- swords hacking through armor, whirling maces smashing visors, blood spurting from severed limbs... Among the combatants: Dunois, Alencon, La Hire and Gilles...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne suddenly sits bolt upright, eyes wide.  Aulon is still asleep in his chair where we last saw him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: French blood is spilling! Aulon awakes as she leaps to her feet, strapping on her breast plate and gauntlets...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've started the battle without me! She tips the two page boys onto the floor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my boys -- why didn't you wake me up?!  Come on, hurry up -- Raymond, saddle my horse -- there's a battle to fight and a war to be won! Raymond runs off and Aulon takes his place, helping Louis to buckle on Jeanne's armor.  She rushes off, leaving Louis to assist Aulon with his own armor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne runs out of the house to where Raymond is standing with her horse.  She mounts it and canters off...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still buckling on his own armor, Aulon spots Jeanne's furled white banner leaning against the wall...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne suddenly remembers she's forgotten her banner.  Sh turns her horse about and canters back, screaming out --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My banner!  I forgot my banner! Aulon appears at the window, holding her banner --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne... here! Jeanne circles about and canters forward...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Throw it! Aulon throws it down to her.  She catches it with one hand, turns and gallops off down the street, the white banner streaming out behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Guard above the main gate sees the French army approaching in full retreat.  He calls down...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open the gates!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sparks fly as the hooves of Jeanne's horse strike the flint cobblestones, swift and clean...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... unlike the hundreds of hooves pounding through mud an mire in the opposite direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne reaches the gates as they are swung open, and the first of the retreating troops make it back to the city - among them, La Hire and Gilles de Rais...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?  Who gave the order to attack?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God knows, but it was a bad idea!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Gilles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were the men confessed?  Where are the priests?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (out of breath)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We didn't take them... we wanted to be fast... wanted to make a surprise attack... Dunois rides up and Jeanne assails him --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dunois... was it you who ordered the attack?  Answer me?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we -- uh -- discuss this later?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sooner is better than later! Jeanne charges forward, into the confused ranks of retreating French soldiers.  Dunois thinks she's gone crazy --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come back... you'll be killed! But Jeanne's not listening.  She's been waiting long enough for this moment, and now she has it, there's no going back.  She stands in her stirrups and shouts out --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Follow me and I will give you victory! La Hire is the first to change his mind, riding up behind Jeanne like Attila the Hun as she gallops forward into th path of the retreating French.  Now the Duke of Alencon joins them, and soon the whole army has turned about -- a immense tidal wave of energy rolling back across the valley...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... toward the astonished English.  One moment they were pursuing their hapless enemies, but now an avenging angel bears down on them, sunlight glinting off her armor.  The start racing back toward their own fortifications:  the bastille St. Loup -- a great fortress amid a network of trenches and tunnels... The French army is finally behaving as a single organism whereas the English cohesion fragments into shards of individual panic -- every man for himself!  They regard Jeanne as a sorceress, and terror spreads like cancer among their ranks.
