They turn and flee back to their own lines, only to be bombarded by a fusillade of their own missiles, poorly aimed at the French. Soon the St. Loup tower is ablaze, the English are forced to abandon their fortress... and the French finally get t celebrate their first victory within living memory. Jeanne has become an object of worship and veneration, an the soldiers crowd about her, cheering her as their savior.  Presently Dunois rides up with his Captains...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a great victory, Jeanne... your victory.  But we must follow it through and pursue the English back to Talbot's camp... unless of course you have another good idea? Jeanne closes her eyes a moment... then smiles at Dunois.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We return to Orleans... across the bridge, at the Tourelles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the bridge has been pulled down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The English are rebuilding it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do you know?! FLASH:  Jeanne and her army are silently moving through a forest.  From her POV, she notices hundreds of fresh trees-stumps...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have been with your counsel, and I have been with mine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The English are moving up the stripped trees we saw earlier from the Tourelles courtyard toward the broken bridge.  Glasdale surveys the operation with satisfaction

dialogues.speaker: ROOF
dialogues.text: Redbeard and the other English Guards on the roof of the Tourelles spot Jeanne's army in the far distance. Redbeard calls down to Glasdale...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glasdale!  Looks like the froggie whore's coming to pay you a visit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne rides at the head of the army, flanked by Dunois, La Hire, Alencon, Gilles, Aulon, Xaintrailles.  They halt in front of a ruined monastery to the south of the Tourelles.  Jeanne gives instructions for the placement o artillery...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Position the long-bows over there, crossbows over there -- and set up Dijon Culverins either side of those trees...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wind will be against us...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wind will be with us! (to the Captains)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do as I say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The English take up their positions along the ramparts of the battery -- a massive, square fortification, surrounde by a deep, empty moat. Jeanne rides forward to the edge of the dry moat, her banner billowing in the breeze, and addresses the English...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glasdale, can you hear me?  You who call me a whore, I pity your soul and the souls of your men.  Yield now to the King of Heaven, and go back to your island...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you, go back to Hell! Jeanne turns and gallops back to the French soldiers as Glasdale turns coolly to Redbeard --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't kill her till I've had my fill of her! -- and walks back to the Tourelles. The French have established a temporary headquarters. Dunois is drawing a map in the dirt and is preparing a battle plan with his Captains...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's plan this attack a little more carefully than this morning...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good idea!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (calling)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My fine soldiers...! Dunois turns to see Jeanne, standing before the army...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This morning, God gave us our first victory, but that was nothing compared to what he is ready to give us now.  I know you are tired and hungry, but I swear to you in the name of the King of Heaven that even if these English were hanging from the clouds by their fingertips, we shall tear them down before nightfall...!  Now, my brave soldiers... let those who love me follow me! With a valiant cry, a thousand soldiers tear forward behind Jeanne.  Dunois is speechless.  Gilles lays a sympathetic hand on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were saying? Jeanne rides at full tilt down into the dry moat, and for the next few minutes, the air is thick with the tumult of battle.  As each successive wave swarms across the moat, so they are met by a fusillade of English flame and steel from the battery above.  But the French respond with equa fervor:  the Dijon Culverins deployed by Jeanne now rain an aerial bombardment of boulders down upon the English, while their arrows darken the sky above... Jeanne reaches the base of the battery.  She leaps down from her horse and starts to climb one of the ladders being thrown up against the wall... but is suddenly struc by an arrow from the rampart above.  She reels -- the ladder sways -- and Aulon catches her in his arms as she falls back to earth.  Redbeard is jokingly furious --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you just killed my woman! The English laugh and jeer, but the French are in dismay at the sight of their Jeanne, unconscious, lying in Aulon's arms, with the arrow wedged deep above her breast

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aulon, La Hire and Xaintrailles carry her to the ruined monastery while the two page boys follow anxiously behind

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter the shell-shattered sanctuary of a gothic chapel where Aulon directs them to lay Jeanne against the wall.  In the distance we can hear the muffled sounds of war, but in here it is strangely quiet. The great war-lords stand in a semi-circle, pathetically wringing their hands, like the seven dwarves bereaving th stricken Snow White.  The sight of tears trickling down L Hire's scarred cheeks is as touching as it is pathetic. Aulon wipes her brow, leaning in very close to feel her pulse and whether her mouth exhales breath.  He turns to Raymond, who stands close by with Louis --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go and find the physician... I saw him with the supplies. Raymond races off...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to take out the arrow now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's in so deep -- I'm afraid she'll bleed to death if we pull it out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There must be something we can do for her for Chrissakes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastic)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  We can pray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good idea... La Hire turns and directs his pledge to the broken stained-glass image of Christ above the trashed altar...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear I'll never swear again in my life if you save her life!  But I'm warning you, if you let her die, then you're the biggest...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't swear... Jeanne stirs, her eyes beginning to open...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He heard me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne... we thought we'd lost you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not so... easily.  Why aren't you... fighting...?  go on... we're almost there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne, you've been badly wounded...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's... it's nothing, it's... Speaking provokes a sudden stab of pain.  She tries to clutch the arrow, but Aulon stops her.  He peels back her shirt, exposing the bloody wound above her pale breast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an arrow, and it's in deep...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must stay still till the physician arrives!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Physicians are a waste of time. You'll have more luck with this charm of mine... it saved my life at Agincourt!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd sooner die than use magic!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne, you will die if that arrow stays in you much longer... Jeanne suddenly seizes the arrow and yanks it out of her body.  Blood spurts -- the suddenness and violence of her action catches the men unaware, and it's a moment before Aulon can stem the flow with his hand.  Jeanne looks at the arrow before throwing it aside...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least this one won't bother us any more.  Now let's get back to the fight! She tries to get up... and collapses, grabbing Aulon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne... please... you must stay calm... you must rest... please! He lays her back down.  Jeanne whispers to him, intimately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright... I promise to rest if you promise... to go back to the battle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I promise... Jeanne smiles -- then suddenly collapses...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shit!  Jeanne... don't die! La Hire breaks off as Raymond arrives back with the Physician...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quickly... do something! The Physician kneels beside her and listens for any sound of life.  All the Captains crowd closer and closer, and a we too move closer, we hear the sound of deep breathing, almost a snore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's sleeping.  Like a baby. La Hire and the others sigh with relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dunois surveys his army's attempt to storm the English battery.  It is now dusk, and without Jeanne the battle has become a half-hearted affair.  He turns to a trumpete as Aulon comes running up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne's alive!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to press home the attack!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the Trumpeter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sound the retreat...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I promised Jeanne we'd fight on!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I made no such promise.  Sound the retreat for the night!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But that was her order!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fed up with taking her orders. She swore she'd defeat the English before nightfall, instead of which she goes and plays the fool and gets herself nearly killed!  Look at the mess we're in!  That's her mess, not mine...!  We're worse off then if she'd never come at all! (to the Trumpeter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... now do as I say and Sound the Retreat! The Trumpeter obeys and signals the evening wrap.  The English jeer and whistle from their impregnable battery a the French head back up the sloping sides of the moat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne lies asleep inside the ruined church, guarded by her two page boys.  A small fire burns nearby to keep her warm, but she is shivering...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She suddenly awakes with a start, then gets up and goes t the fire.  She kneels down... puts her hands in the flames... and scoops up a handful of ash.  She paints her face with the black ash, like a native warrior, then stands back up, turning to face a small army...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My brave soldiers, do you believe in God? The Army cries out "Yeesssss!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then let God's punishment be done: Eye for eye... ... and a sudden FLASH of lightning transforms some of he men into skeletons...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... tooth for tooth...! (another flash)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... burn for burn...! (another flash)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... life for a life! ... a final FLASH, and her whole army is now a seething swarm of SKELETONS.  With a curdling cry of vengeance the race forward, passing either side of her... Jeanne turns to see the skeleton army heading across a bizarre bridge and onto the moonlit battery, flowing either side of the 8 year-old BOY she saw in the woods as a child.  Intrigued, Jeanne follows him, but by the time she reaches him, the boy has disappeared.  The skeletons have also vanished, to be replaced by an army of little English boys in man-sized armor, heading toward a distant figure. The boy-soldiers are being welcomed by the beautiful MAN Jeanne saw earlier.  He smiles at her, extending his arms in a Christ-like gesture of embrace... As Jeanne approaches him, others turn to welcome her -- Aulon, Dunois, Alencon... finally La Hire, holding out hi arms --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne, come here my friend, my soldier... in my arms! La Hire scoops her up into his bear-like arms and swings her round... suddenly, over his shoulder she spots a familiar figure:  her dead sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catherine?? She breaks from La Hire and runs to Catherine, throwing her arms around her and sobbing with joy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Catherine... oh, Catherine -- I knew you wouldn't leave me...! They stand for a moment, embracing each other, while La Hire and the other Captains applaud Jeanne's victory.  Th beautiful young MAN approaches them, but we now see that he has a sword clasped behind his back... Catherine's face contorts in pain.  She slumps forward, the sword in her back.  Beyond her, the beautiful MAN has transformed into the grotesque Blackbeard, who roars with laughter as Jeanne holds her dying sister...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Avenge me... avenge me...! A circle of fire forms around them, with skeleton soldier dancing in the flames... Blackbeard's echoing laugh is gradually superimposed by real laughter and a familiar voice...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey... Frenchies... what happened to your precious angel, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All is quiet, the troops lie sleeping.  Redbeard calls through the mist from the raised drawbridge spanning the dry moat linking the battery to the French camp --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frenchies, you hear me?  What happened to your little virgin? Jeanne is awake.  She listens to Redbeard...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what happened... we sent her back to Hell so she can go fuck with the Devil! Now Jeanne is caressing her horse while Redbeard taunts..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you going to do, Frenchies? Why not come out and fight?  Or are you too busy praying to bring your witch back from the dead?  Do you hear me? Suddenly Jeanne emerges from the mist, riding her horse and brandishing her banner --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear you!  May God forgive your blasphemy... but I never can! She turns and disappears back into the mist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Redbeard blinks in amazement.  He turns to another soldier --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go and wake up Glasdale...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne rides along the columns of sleeping soldiers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on -- wake up -- sound trumpets and to horse! The dazed and sleepy French drag themselves from their straw beds.  Dunois emerges from his tent, bleary and half-naked...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're taking back the Tourelles!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Guard shakes Glasdale awake...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's happening?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lord... the French witch just came back from the dead. Glasdale hauls himself from his bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne supervises her men as they push a huge siege tower toward the dry moat.  She rides over to Aulon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get all the men to horse and ready to follow... Aulon goes as Dunois hurries over...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne, what are you doing with that... you've got it back to front...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know what I'm doing, so either lend a hand or go back to bed!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Redbeard watches in bewilderment as the siege machine starts to materialize through the mist...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell she's playing at...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glasdale is equally perplexed, gazing out from his garret window across the battery.  An archer is by his side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crazy bitch... she doesn't even know how to use it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The French wheel the enormous siege tower toward a wooden lip above the dry moat.  The drawbridge is firmly raised on the far side.  Redbeard's complacent expression change as he suddenly realizes what's about to happen...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh shit... He backs away as the machine reaches the lip.  Suddenly i topples forward, crashing down on top of the raised drawbridge and demolishing it beneath its enormous weight...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From his elevated viewpoint, Glasdale watches in horror a Aulon leads the French cavalry across the siege machine bridge that now spans the dry moat, giving them access to the battery...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raise the drawbridge! The Archer passes Glasdale's order along -- a chain message that reaches the gate-keeper, who promptly starts to turn the winch...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the French swarm onto the battery, Redbeard and his soldiers turn tail and race back toward the second drawbridge into the Tourelles...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait for me! The bridge is already being winched up... Redbeard is the first to reach it... with a desperate leap he manages to grab the lip of the bridge and scramble over...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... rolling down into the sanctuary of the Tourelles on the far side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His comrades are less fortunate, and are slaughtered by the advancing French. Jeanne urges her troops forward, her white banner billowing in the breeze, but with the drawbridge raised, there is no way for them to enter the Tourelles.  The English hurl fresh insults -- and bombards -- from the battlements above, and the French are forced to take cove behind two ruined buildings on the battery. Jeanne rides across to a ruined barn where several carts are stacked with felled tree-trunks.  She spots La Hire..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prepare these as battering-rams!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the use?  The drawbridge is up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not for long... Under a hail of English arrows, Jeanne rides back across the open battery to a ruined house on the other side.  Sh sees Aulon and dismounts...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The king said you're his finest archer...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come with me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne leads Aulon through the ruined house to the far end, where a window overlooks the river-moat that separates the battery from the Tourelles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see those wooden beams...? Jeanne points to the two beams supporting the chains of the drawbridge further along...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want you to set them on fire!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glasdale spots Jeanne running back across the battery.  H summons his Archer, pointing her out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kill her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne leaves the ruined house and spots Gilles standing with Alencon.  As she approaches, Gilles spots the archer in Glasdale's window far above, taking aim.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gilles -- fetch the Dijon Culverins and place them over there... Jeanne turns her back -- the Archer fires -- Gilles holds up his shield -- the arrow strikes it -- and Jeanne turns back, unaware that he has just saved her life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perfectly. Gilles heads off, leaving Alencon looking left out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And me... what can I do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um... round up the horses and keep them safe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good idea. Leaving Alencon to his task, Jeanne rides off... ... and THUMP!  a flaming arrow lands in one of the drawbridge beams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An English soldier peers down to see both beams ablaze...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fetch some water! The command is passed down the line -- a bucket is lowere into the river and hauled back up -- the bucket rushed up stone stairs to the soldier on the battlements...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meanwhile Jeanne returns to Dunois and La Hire --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand by with the battering-rams...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need another ten minutes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bridge won't wait!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave it to me... Back on the battlements, the bucket of water is passed up to the Soldier, who tries to pour it over the edge and onto the blazing beam.  Aulon spots him from below and fires a flaming arrow -- it pierces the soldier, who pour the water on himself, extinguishing the flames...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TIGHT SHOTS:  hands wind the handle of a bobbin -- a device is activated -- a lever thrown -- a grille slides sideways...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The beams collapse -- the support chains give way -- and the drawbridge comes crashing down.  Beyond it is a portcullis, but to La Hire's exuberant volunteers this is no barrier.  Carrying buckets of flaming oil, they charge forward... ... but as they race across the drawbridge, a sudden volley of high-velocity arrows discharge from the lower apertures of the portcullis, felling them before they eve get halfway across the bridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The English cackle with delight at the sight of the dying French writhing in the flaming oil.  Redbeard -- in charg of the multiple balista -- orders the device to be reloaded, then yells through the upper portcullis...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, what happened to the whore? Sorry... virgin!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dunois views the massacred soldiers lying on the bridge amid the dying flames.  Jeanne is about to mount her horse...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Send her over here and she won't stay a virgin for long!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne, don't do it!  Just stop and think for once!  Don't you see?  The gate's a trap... and he's the bait! Redbeard roars with laughter as Jeanne yells back --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I take pity on your soul, Englishman!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Redbeard checks the reloading of the balista...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the matter?  Frightened of a little English stuffing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne gently puts her arm around her horse's neck, whispering to it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must both be brave... She kisses it lightly, then grabs her banner from Louis, calling out to the others --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you see my banner touch the door, the fortress is ours! ... and away she rides, across the drawbridge, still pile with the slaughtered men from the first attack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and... fire!! Another volley of arrows discharges from the portcullis and Jeanne's horse collapses.  The English cheer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From his garret window high above, Glasdale sees Jeanne spread-eagled next to her dead horse on the drawbridge below.  He turns to his servant with a grin...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This time she won't be back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aulon gapes in horror... but then suddenly Jeanne is back up on her feet again.  Gripping her banner, she dashes forward toward the portcullis, implanting it just as Redbeard opens a little sliding grille -- Jeanne jabs her banner through --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... impaling Redbeard's skull on the far side!  His body crumples to the ground, wedged between the base of the portcullis and the balista.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne runs back across the drawbridge, crying out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is ours!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the Tourelles, the English try to operate the reloaded balista.  But Redbeard's corpse is wedged so tightly that they can't move it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne moves aside as La Hire and his men heave the carts laden with tree-trunk battering-rams across the bridge...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glasdale has seen enough...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... He tears down into the courtyard, mustering soldiers as he goes --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To arms!  To arms! With a triumphant battle-cry, the French charge their battering-ram into the portcullis...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... demolishing it like matchwood, then storm inside the fortress.  Glasdale cries out to his troops --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Soldiers... In the name of the king, I want you to kill these French dogs until there's none left! The English troops swarm either side of the broken portcullis, forcing most of the French back onto the battery...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: La Hire lets out a blood-curdling, primeval war-cry and charges forward to meet the English wave head on.  Jeanne is caught in the middle, buffeted from side to side by a sea of heaving, sweating, bleeding bodies... In this melee it is impossible to know who is friend or foe, and the images become so blurred that we and Jeanne are soon lost in a mist of dust and noise...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLASH:  our eyes are momentarily blinded by the sun... an when we return, we find Jeanne in the middle of the battery, but now totally alone, weaving her sword through the air in SLOW MOTION as she once did with her stick...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FLASH:  Jeanne is still weaving the air with her sword, but she is now a little girl of eight, playing in the field we first saw her in.  The small BOY looks at her, smiling... FLASH:  Jeanne continues to play, but is now 17, and the boy is now a young MAN, still smiling.  He calls out to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne... what are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Playing... She sweeps her sword and decapitates a flower.  Blood flows from the stalk... Jeanne looks at it, more in childish curiosity than astonishment or horror.  She looks at the sword, the blade now streaked with blood...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne... what are you doing? Jeanne pauses, looks at him steadily... and suddenly notices that blood is trickling down his face.  A SHAFT O LIGHT blazes, wind billows... and suddenly it's winter, the trees naked, heavy with snow...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you done to me, Jeanne? Jeanne looks horrified.  The Man puts his hands to her face, gazing deep into her eyes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have you done to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne is screaming at Aulon, who is gripping her blood- splattered face as the Man did...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne, calm down, do you hear me? Are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's over, Jeanne.  We won, just as you said! Jeanne looks about her in a daze.  La Hire strides over, arms extended, extravagant as always --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne, come here my friend, my soldier... in my arms! Jeanne starts laughing -- she can't believe it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We... won?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Won?!  Such a small word will never do!  This is victory, Jeanne, this is... glory! He scoops her up in his bear-like arms like an ebullient lover, both laughing in the moment.  He slowly turns her around, breathing in a great lungful of air and savoring the smell of what Jeanne now sees over his shoulder:  the entire courtyard, knee-deep in bodies and bits of bodies -- including the gallant Xaintrailles. Jeanne too can smell the reek of fresh, warm gore.  Her laugh turns to a cry of anguish.  La Hire sets her back down...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne -- what's the matter?? Jeanne is utterly horrified... her legs tremble... amber liquid trickles down her armor...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You call this... glory...?  All this... this blood... this smell of...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... the smell of victory, Jeanne! Mmmmmmm!  I love it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not possible... Jeanne sees a French soldier of meager wit, hauling a dying English soldier onto his knees for some obscure purpose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look disappointed... Isn't this what you wanted?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... not like this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For weeks you've been asking for this... well now you have it! The Soldier is about to smash the Englishman's mouth with a mace.  Jeanne snaps out of her momentary stupor and races across, stumbling over the dead bodies...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop it!  What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing... just taking his teeth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you can't just kill a man for his teeth!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?  He has good teeth...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because... because you just can't!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eye for an eye, tooth for a tooth... Jeanne ignores the laconic Gilles...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Besides, what about these...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's different... I mean... we were fighting for a... for a cause! Gilles grins, but La Hire looks genuinely bemused at Jeanne's behavior.  The soldier shrugs, unimpressed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not me.  He's my prisoner... I can take his teeth if I want to... He is about to smash the teeth...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! She throws herself in front of the startled Frenchman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take mine instead -- here -- smash mine first!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne... get up... this is ridiculous...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you kill him, you kill me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne... let him do it.  One more dead body's not going to make any difference, so who cares?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I care!  And I care because God cares!  All life is precious to God -- even his -- even yours and mine...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne... the man hasn't been paid for six months -- that's his only reward.  Let him take a few teeth...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few teeth... that's the price of his life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here -- take this instead. She wrenches a ring from her finger and flings it at the soldier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's mine now. Jeanne cuts the Englishman's bonds...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you... get out. The English soldier doesn't wait for further prompting. Gilles claps...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bravo!  What about all the other hundreds of prisoners?  Do we let them go too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe... I don't know... but first we have to confess...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne marches her blood-splattered captains into the church and up the aisle toward the rubble-strewn altar. She sees a terrified Franciscan PRIEST and grabs hold of him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please... we have to be confessed... all of us... now!  I know it's not normal custom, but sometimes... you know... we have to make an exception and... and today is an exception... The Priest looks confounded.  Jeanne turns to the Captains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's going to confess us.  Kneel! All but La Hire kneel, although their armor is stiff at the joints.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne, if you don't mind... I'll stay standing... this armor... it's a nightmare to get back up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said, kneel! Jeanne raises her sword and brings the flat blade whackin against the back of his legs.  La Hire crumples, and Jeanne turns to the Priest...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please... we're ready... begin! The Priest is totally lost... he begins to mumble a few words in Latin just as a soldier burst in --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (breathless)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The English... they're forming up... thousands of them... on the far side of the river... The Captains look anxiously at Jeanne.  She hesitates a moment, then gazes up at the battered crucifix on the altar and closes her eyes in prayer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne opens her eyes.  It is dawn, and two silent armies are drawn up facing one another:  four thousand Englishme on the left, two thousand Frenchmen on the right.  They have barely had time to recover from the Tourelles, and the lust for battle is gone.  We sense that this is going to be a blood bath that nobody wants. Franciscan monks move among them, sprinkling them with holy water in final absolution.  The battle lines are too far apart for the English to see any details, but the sight of massed soldiers kneeling before an invisible God is an awesome spectacle. Jeanne and the Captains are mounted, facing the English.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well...?  Shall we go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The English won't wait. Jeanne hesitates...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne, no... But Dunois silences him, indicating to Gilles that he should accompany her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone. Dunois is again obliged to comply, and Gilles hangs back. From the English lines, we see a small, solitary figure emerge from the massed ranks of French soldiers. Jeanne moves halfway between the two armies.  The English soldiers watch her, mesmerized, while their captains remain motionless. In the middle of the field, Jeanne halts.  From the Frenc POV she looks dangerously vulnerable.  The English commander -- TALBOT -- draws up alongside his Captains, watching her with grey eyes and an expression of stone. Only we see that Jeanne is crying.  She rubs the tears away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a message for your King Henry.  It is a message from God. The English stand silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go home... Go now, in peace.  If you don't go now, you will be buried in this field.  I've seen enough blood for today, but if you want more, I can't stop you.  I can only warn you that it will be your blood, not ours. Talbot whispers something to one of his Captains.  He withdraws to pass the message on.  Jeanne -- and her French captains -- try to gauge the English mood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm waiting for your answer. Now the English Captains start moving along their flanks. Something's about to happen.  Dunois and the French watch in dismay as the English flanks move aside, exposing thei dreaded archers.  Jeanne closes her eyes, tears brimming.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, Lord... don't... don't let this happen... don't leave me... The English archers take a step back, their cavalry move slowly forward, then turn to their right, the men letting them through.  Dunois turns to La Hire...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never wait for miracles.  Stand by to attack... The serried ranks of English infantry close in, then halt We're ready for the worst, and it takes Jeanne -- and us -- a full twenty seconds to realize what is happening: the English are leaving.  First the cavalry, then the infantry, finally the archers themselves. Jeanne cannot believe her eyes.  She burst out laughing and crying at the same time.  The French captains gape in astonishment.  Finally La Hire can contain himself no longer --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By God and all the saints... now that's what I call a bloody miracle! The French burst into jubilation...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the cheering builds, we see a Messenger race along a corridor and burst into the throne room.  Charles slowly rises on hearing the joyous news, clapping his hands in delight -- not least at the discomfort of Tremoille and Regnault.  But Yolande shares his enthusiasm, although we sense that the news comes as no great surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cheering continues as another Messenger races along a similar stone corridor and bursts in on the haggard Duke of BEDFORD.  He is the English regent, and is in council with several others, including the Bishop of Beauvais -- one Pierre CAUCHON.  As Bedford hears the news, the cheering FADES.  He rises from his chair...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want that girl.  I want her burned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd goes wild as Jeanne rides through the streets o Rheims, carrying her banner in triumph.  She is followed by Aulon and her two page boys, and is accompanied by soldiers who do their best to hold the ecstatic crowd at bay.  At the far end of the street:  a magnificent cathedral.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Backstage pandemonium as Charles is readied for his imminent coronation.  A glamorous Gilles tries to help hi into his ermine robe; Tremoille stands with Archbishop Regnault, adjusting his gold-trimmed cloak.  An ancient BISHOP -- palsied and pushing 80 -- stands by, hands a-trembling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's too tight -- where's the seamstress?  And that... (pointing to crown)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... that's meant to be a crown? Don't you have something more -- more regal? A young Priest is holding the dowdy crown...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The English took the real one...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I asked for a grandiose coronation, and this is what you give me?  This whole thing's going to be a complete fiasco...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sire, we were only given three days to prepare -- three days! -- Why, your father's coronation took three months! Charles turns to Tremoille --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's probably right -- let's call a delay...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no time, sire -- we can't hold up the ceremony... there's no telling when the English might come back... they're only ten leagues away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let them come!  Let them see who's the true king of France! Further away, Dunois is examining himself in a looking- glass.  He is standing with Gilles de Rais, both resplendent in their armor, now cleaned and polished...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been muddy for so long, I forgot how good it looked when cleaned up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you remember to clean up what's inside as well? Dunois ribs him with his elbow, both laughing.  In anothe corner, Alencon is fast asleep. Charles is still grumbling...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those damn English... we should be doing this in Paris... in Notre Dame -- much more prestigious -- and twice as big as this one! Yolande, who has been standing quietly in the shadows wit Richmond, steps forward...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is the sacred place that matters, Charles -- not the size.  Am I correct, Bishop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh yes, my lady.  All true kings of France must first be anointed in our great cathedral of Rheims... with the holy oil of Clovis... for it was within these very walls that Saint Remy received the sacred oil from Heaven, brought to him by a white dove for the anointing of King Clovis...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, yes -- well let's just get on with it, shall we?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... before the English turn up and spoil everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They wouldn't dare!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wouldn't be so sure.  It only takes one of them -- in disguise -- Gilles pulls a sharp dagger -- Charles looks petrified...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... with a good dagger... that's all it takes... Gilles lifts the dagger... and snips a loose thread from Charles's shoulder...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... to ruin the whole thing. Gilles sheaths his dagger, but Charles is now panicking. He glances at those around him as though one of them migh be a spy.  Gilles moves away, and Charles turns to his pages --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hurry up! Further away, the Bishop's assistant Canon hurries in, holding a small jar --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Grace, there can be no anointing!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What in heaven's name are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The holy oil of Clovis -- it's all gone! The ancient Archbishop can scarcely believe his ears.  He peers inside the little jar just as Yolande arrives with Richmond...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gone??  But that's impossible -- it's magic oil... I mean miraculous oil -- it can never be exhausted...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look for yourself! The Canon offers it to the Bishop, but Yolande intervenes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Problem? He hands her the little jar...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand... the holy oil of Clovis... it was quite full the last time I saw it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And when was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... at the coronation of King Charles VI...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty years ago?  I'm not surprised it's gone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No no, you don't understand -- this is no ordinary oil -- this is miraculous... this oil was brought from heaven by a white dove to crown King Clovis in this... very... cathedral... Yolande has moved away, to be replaced by the hideously- scarred Richmond.  The Bishop's voice trails as he sees Yolande beyond him, taking an oil lamp from the wall and pouring a little oil into the jar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: W-w-what are you doing?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Performing a miracle. Richmond curtails any protest with a toothy grin. There's a growing SOUND of excitement coming from beyond. Finally Jeanne appears in the doorway, carrying her banne and followed by her faithful page boys, Louis and Raymond La Hire nudges Alencon awake as she passes, giving an admiring whistle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Jeanne... come here...!  This whole coronation idea of yours is a fiasco... nothing is ready...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... You look wonderful...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and my crown doesn't fit and... (breaking off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?? She looks up and down, appraising him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You look like a king. Charles melts.  TRUMPETS SOUND from the great Cathedral beyond...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two tiers of boys sing in plainsong as Charles enters through a small door and into the vastness of the crowded Cathedral.  It is filled to capacity, with Jeanne's comrades-in-arms filling the front pews like eager fans, straining for a glimpse of her. Tremoille waddles behind Charles, with Regnault, Yolande and Richmond in tow.  Next, the two page boys -- and then at last the main attraction as far as this congregation i concerned -- the crowd lets out an audible gasp as Jeanne enters in her white armor, carrying her proud, war-scarre banner and escorted by Jean d'Aulon. La Hire is so moved at the sight that he has to wipe away big soppy tears (for sentimentality was ever the flip-sid of cruelty).  Alencon and Dunois likewise gaze at their adored one, though Gilles is perhaps more taken with the cherubic choir boys... Jeanne trembles with emotion.  This is the peak of her career, and she knows it, and she's making the most of it As the little procession reaches the nave, all but Charle filter aside.  He walks forward alone to where Archbishop Regnault is standing -- a few paces -- then stops, turns -- and holds out his hands to Jeanne. The crowd gasp with approval at the unprecedented gesture... La Hire briefly claps, before being dug in the ribs by Gilles... but the kingly act provokes jealous looks from Regnault and Tremoille... Jeanne hesitates, then is almost willed on by the crowd into joining Charles.  She stands a little aside as he kneels.  Regnault sprinkles the Holy Oil on his sovereign's head...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With this sacred oil, blessed by the hand of God the Father Almighty, we do anoint thee Charles Valois... Regnault breaks off:  there's a commotion at the back of the cathedral.  Charles looks around -- anxious faces tur -- soldiers draw their swords -- is it the English?? Bored by the ceremony, young Louis has been kicking legs again, and one of the guards is nursing a bruised shin. With all eyes suddenly upon him, Louis flushes -- and is quickly taken in hand by Yolande.  After the brief interruption, Regnault continues...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... we do anoint thee Charles Valois, Sovereign Lord and King of this great kingdom of France, charging that ye defend the faith of our Mother Holy Church so long as ye shall live... It could almost be the marriage ceremony.  Jeanne watches in tears, trembling with emotion as the Archbishop takes the crown and holds it above Charles' head, then slowly, slowly lowers it... As he does so, an eerie SOUND, like a bullet in slow- motion coming straight at us... followed by a cry from Jeanne...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne gasps -- sways... Torrential rain, sweeping across the grey, mud-filled moa in great curtains.  She's standing on the bank above the moat, looking across at the massive city walls where ladders have been set up.  Aulon catches up with her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne...!  Are you alright?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  Yes, I'm fine... (yelling out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We need more brushwood! (to Aulon)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you staring at me like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because there's an arrow in your leg. She looks down and there it is, poking out her leg:  an arrow has penetrated her armor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So there is... She hadn't realized -- and doesn't seem that bothered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... but that's no reason for you to stop.  You can still climb a ladder, can't you?  So go on then... climb! Aulon looks across at the endless ladders, disappearing into the mist and smoke at the top of the gigantic wall. Jeanne calls out to her page, Raymond --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Raymond!  Over here! Raymond hurries over...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pull it out. Raymond looks terrified --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pull it out! Raymond grips the arrow while Jeanne gazes across at one of the ladders laden with Frenchmen.  As he pulls it out, the ladder falls back, plunging the soldiers to their deaths.  Jeanne gasps in pain... La Hire and Gilles are further along the bank...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is no good!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No good?  This is a disaster! Gilles stumbles along the bank to Jeanne...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne... The men are exhausted!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, but so is the enemy -- they're falling back -- Paris is ours...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne... we're not enough...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... bring up the reinforcements!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reinforcements?  Where?? Jeanne waves vaguely behind her --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right behind us -- Dunois with another then thousand men!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne, look behind you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never look behind -- only ahead! Gilles grips her by the shoulders, forcing her to turn an look behind.  At most, a hundred bedraggled soldiers, limping amid the carnage in the moat.  Jeanne stares at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know how to count?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I do?  Bring them up!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne... that is not ten thousand reinforcements -- that is one hundred very loyal but very tired soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But... where is Dunois... where are the men the king promised me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He never sent them... Don't you understand?  He doesn't want this war anymore... he has his crown now, that's all he ever wanted...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But my voices... they promised me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To hell with your voices -- it's time to face facts!  We have nothing to do here... none of us... not even you.  You should go home, Jeanne. Jeanne stares at them, in shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't believe me anymore?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We still believe in you, Jeanne.  If it were up to me, I'd chase every goddamn Englishman into the ocean. But it's not up to us anymore -- it's up to the king... Jeanne looks at him, suddenly furious --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- Jeanne storms along a corridor, her two page boys doin their best to catch up with her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She bursts in on Charles, who is cavorting in a bath-tub with a few frivolous females.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, this is an unexpected pleasure.  Ladies, let me introduce you to the celebrated Jeanne... The damsels titter...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get them out of here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now hold on -- you're not captain here... on the battlefield perhaps, but not in the royal bedchamber!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you betray me?  Paris was ours for the taking!  All I needed was another few hundred men... Why did you take back the army you gave me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gave you?  Well now, I wouldn't quite put it like that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bluntly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how would you put it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... we are, of course, enormously grateful for your past efforts, but your task is done.  Now it's time for negotiation... and after many months of skillful work, our dear Tremoille is about to seal a treaty with our Burgundian friends who will no longer lend their support to the English.  You see, my dear Jeanne... as it is written in the Bible, "to everything there is a season:  a time for war, and a time for peace"...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peace will only be got from the English at the end of a lance!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you have to be so bloodthirsty?  Do you enjoy it?  All that blood and noise and pain? Diplomacy is far more civilized... far safer... and far cheaper... Jeanne angrily holds out a fistful of letters --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have letters here from towns under siege -- Compiegne, Provins, Melin -- where the people are starving, begging God on their knees to help them... and I'm here to answer their prayers -- and you want to stop me? France does not belong to you, Charles -- she belongs to God.  And if you won't help me save her, I shall do it alone! Jeanne slings the letters in his face and marches out of the room.  Charles turns to the girls with a weary sigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If only she would just go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aulon reaches the door to a chapel to find it guarded by Louis and Raymond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't go in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get out...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aulon enters to find Jeanne crumpled by the altar.  He kneels beside her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne... the king has ordered us not to ride with you anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... what am I supposed to do now? Aulon hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do your voices say? Jeanne pauses... a long moment, whether or not to confide Finally, and with a bleakness not sensed in her before...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've abandoned me... like everyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What... what do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been weeks since they spoke to me.  Since the coronation... no signs... nothing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe their silence is a sign...? Maybe it's a sign to go home?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not time yet.  My mission is not over yet.  There is still more I must do before I can really -- finally -- go home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But how do you know that these -- these voices aren't really just -- well, you. Jeanne stares at him in bemusement -- then suddenly laughs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well of course they're me!  That's how God talks to me.  If you listen hard enough, even you can hear him. Everyone can hear him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I hear so many voices... one voice saying one thing, another voice saying the opposite -- love your enemy, kill your enemy -- what is good, what is evil...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All you have to do is stop talking and just listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But how do you know what you hear is the truth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know it.  I feel it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You make it sound so simple...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The truth is always simple... it's you, Jean, who's making things complicated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me?!  It's not me, it's God who makes everything complicated!  If he's all-powerful, why not let the English stay on their island in the first place?  And why let this war go on for a hundred years?  And why send you out to fight when a girl like you should be at home with your family?  Why, why?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... even you don't believe in me anymore...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne... I believe in you... more than anyone... Aulon's hand touches Jeanne's hair.  He leans forward, as though being drawn by her eyes and mouth...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I just wish I could... I want to... to help you... The moment is a little too intense.  They gaze at each other, then Jeanne suddenly pulls away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you really want to help me, there's one thing you can do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell the king to give me more men. Jeanne goes, leaving Aulon alone, deliberating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne and her pages mount their horses and ride off...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aulon walks through a small antechamber and is about to knock at a door when he pauses, hearing familiar voices.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to stop her, your majesty. If she raises her own army and attacks the Burgundians at Compiegne, all my months of painful negotiations will have been in vain! Aulon draws closer, shocked at what he hears...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tremoille is right.  She behaves as though she were God!  It's high time she found out who's really in command.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Regnault, Tremoille and Yolande coil about Charles like serpents.  Charles looks at them all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's true.  There's only one king... people need to be reminded of that. Nevertheless... Jeanne has done so much for us...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I assure you, Charles, the Maiden has no greater admirer than myself. But whatever our personal feelings, we cannot allow her to conduct her own private war.  For the sake of the kingdom, it is imperative that you stop her going to Compiegne...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I can't stop her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well if you don't, I'm sure the Burgundians will be happy to oblige. If they capture her at Compiegne...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... no one can blame us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I don't know... it'll sound like we... betrayed her...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Noooo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good heavens no!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, Charles.  If God is still with her, she will be victorious.  We're not her judges... we're just spectators.  Let her go to Compiegne, as you let her go to Orleans, and let God decide her fate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But... her army's so small now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then her faith will have to be bigger. Yolande gives Richmond a significant look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aulon can scarcely believe what he has heard!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A table smashes against a stone wall... a chair splinters in fragments.  Aulon is in a frenzy, smashing up furniture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aulon rides out from the castle...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne and her meager band of soldiers have paused for food.  Aulon makes his way through the trees -- and finds Jeanne a little apart from the others, with her two page boys...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne... I need to speak to you. (pointedly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone. Jeanne glances at him a moment, then nods for Louis and Raymond to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did the king listen to you? Aulon blushes... clears his throat...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne, I... I love you, Jeanne.  I love you and... I want to marry you. Jeanne is a little taken aback, but is genuinely touched.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not what I asked... Why do you want to marry me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You listen to your voices, I listen to my heart. Jeanne looks at him a beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did the king say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He said that... he's making a treaty with the Duke of Burgundy and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a trap!  They're buying time till they can bring over more soldiers from England!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did your voices tell you that?  You told me you hadn't heard them for months...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or maybe it's Jeanne who's in a trap -- her own trap -- a downward spiral that she can't stop?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you come back to marry me or to insult me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To marry you. A beat... then she looks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will ask my voices... if they come back one day.  Meanwhile... I'm going to Compiegne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne... I have been hearing voices -- and believe me, those voices left me in no doubt that you must not go to Compiegne! She looks at him a moment, knowing that he speaks the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne... I believe in you -- but can you believe in me for once? Don't go... even if you don't want to marry me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would like to marry you.  But I have already promised myself... to God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But... you've done so much for God as it is... can't you do something for yourself for once -- for Jeanne?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But it is what I want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To be killed in battle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If God wants me to win, he will find a way.  And if he wants me to die... if he wants me back... then that's fine too.  Then I'll be with him forever. She has a dreamy, faraway look -- one with which Aulon cannot compete.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Will you at least let me stay with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would not be the same without you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SHARP CUT to a Man being felled by a cudgel.  We are in the middle of the battle, and things are not going well for the French.  The citizens and their MAYOR watch anxiously from the draw-bridge and the town walls.  Nearb stands a familiar face:  the battle-scarred Richmond.  Th Mayor and Richmond exchange a glance that chills... Jeanne is struggling to keep her banner aloft... then a cry from close by, and to her horror she sees Raymond collapse with an arrow in his breast.  His faithful companion Louis races to his side, throwing his arms around him. Jeanne jumps down from her horse, but by the time she reaches him, his eyes are closed.  Louis looks up at her, tears brimming.  Aulon rides up alongside Jeanne...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must sound the retreat!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not yet! With the enemy bearing down, there's no time to pause...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From high on the town walls, the Mayor surveys the distan battle.  Richmond is standing a short distance away.  He gives him a sign.  The Mayor turns to a Guard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't risk the town's safety. Raise the drawbridge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Jeanne rides back with Aulon, she spots Richmond beyon the drawbridge inside the town.  There's a brief exchange between them, a locking of eyes.  Jeanne turns to Aulon..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get back inside the town and see if the English are attacking from the other side!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But... why... what's the point?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do as I say!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to stay with you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's an order! Aulon looks almost shocked.  He backs away, then turns hi horse about and rides back across the drawbridge and into the town.  Seconds later, the drawbridge begins to rise, and Jeanne is trapped. She tries to fight her way clear of the advancing English but they encircle her.  She lashes out with the flat of her sword, trying to keep their swords and lances at bay. The noose tightens -- her horse starts to panic... but strangely there's a smile on her face, as though she sees the end coming, this end that she so desires:  to die on battlefield in penance for the blood shed in her name. Suddenly a BOLT slices through BONE -- -- and Jeanne's horse collapses from under her.  She roll to the ground, springing back to her feet as the English close in.  Again she flays the air with her sword, but it becomes heavier and heavier as her energy finally begins to drain. A huge iron ball smashes her sword in two -- now she has no weapon but her fists.  Yet still she lashes out, like a fox cornered by hounds.  Another blow -- she falls to the ground, her face gazing up.  Her eyes soften, and again that smile -- Her POV:  High above the dust and smoke and flame of battle -- a little patch of blue...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and Jeanne falls into the field of her childhood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Lord... -- the sky brightens -- the SUN dazzles -- space/time dilates... with her arms wide open, Jeanne offers herself to the skies --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take me...! Nature starts to consume her, integrating her as a part o the whole... clouds, seasons and wind become one in an apocalyptic ballet... grass, flowers and roots consume her... the camera suddenly pulls back so fast and far tha within seconds the earth has become a revolving sphere in the darkness of space... FLASH:  the sphere now becomes a four-dimensional torus, fluid, dynamic ring, evolving in and out of space... FLASH:  the torus blinks, and the dark center becomes a BLUE EYE, the same diameter as Jeanne's.  overwhelmed by this vision.  A shadow of a MAN clutching a mace is reflected in the blueness... SHARP CUT to the Man as he slams her... WHAM! BLACK.  Then a zillion stars evolve from the darkness, slowly rotating inversely toward a central point as thoug returning to the origin of space/time in one single dimensionless point of light -- which then suddenly EXPLODES... At the same moment a HUGE EYE blinks open -- the EYE of Jeanne...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne's eyes search a darkness that gradually resolves into the grim, dank confines of a dungeon.  She sits bolt upright, as though awakening from a nightmare. She is on a wooden bed, her face bruised and tumefied.  A few inches away is a MAN, one side of his shaved head catching a sliver of light.  He's laughing at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe it... your romantic vision of death, with all that grass growing everywhere... I must admit, you have a great imagination.  Or maybe not great enough.  Death is much more simple... FLASH:  A dead body lying in the silent forest, a trickle of blood running from his mouth...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... after a few months it gets more interesting... FLASH:  Same shot, only now the body is wriggling... FLASH:  The body is now reduced to skin and bones...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... then -- after a year -- it finally becomes romantic... FLASH:  The same spot in the forest, but now there is no sign of the body. Jeanne shakes her head...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who... who are you...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am that I am. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't like my face? (evidently not)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe you prefer this one... His face melts into the little boy, sitting on a throne i the middle of the wood.  She gazes at him in bewilderment --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too young maybe?  How about this one? The boy becomes the young man she saw in the forest. Jeanne is breathless.  The Man is invading her most secre memories.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better, no...?  But incomplete. Suddenly his face is flooded with blood, like the image o the man she saw during the battle of Orleans... Jeanne SCREAMS, covering her face...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get thee behind me.  Satan! The Man smiles, unaffected by her outburst.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you to even think you can know the difference between good and evil?  Are you God?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... no... I'm just a messenger... He needs me... a higher calling... Suddenly the man starts to bellow -- the walls tremble -- the bellow becomes a roar... clouds boil behind his head...

dialogues.speaker: POSSIBLY NEED
dialogues.text: Jeanne can no longer stop her tears...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... I thought...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know... please... tell me I'm dead...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... don't know... what do you want from me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing.  I'm here to set you free... The Man holds up his hand as though in judgment -- A hand slams across her face -- -- and she wakes up, nursing her hot cheek.  In front of her:  the rough English guard who just struck her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said, smile!  You have visitors. The door opens, and a smart delegation arrives in her cell, led by a thin reed of a man, the Duke of BURGUNDY and his right-arm, DIJON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His Grace the Duke of Burgundy. Jeanne stares at him, confused...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... here is the famous Jeanne... Savior of Orleans... terror of the English?  You look pretty ordinary to me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Am I... am I dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead you're worthless, darling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where... where am I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guess. She looks about her dismal confines...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My king will pay any ransom you ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your king?  Ah yes, of course... What's he going to pay me with? Cows?  Chickens?  I prefer gold, and the English have plenty.  I wonder how much they'll pay... to have the Witch of Orleans in their clutches? Those English are so arrogant, they can't accept the idea of being defeated by a peasant girl... it has to have been the devil's work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God defeated the English, not me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And God who allowed you to be caught? Jeanne hadn't thought about that before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Personally I don't believe in God, and I don't believe in the Devil either.  That's why I'm never disappointed. (to Dijon)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sell her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aulon goes to see the King in his chamber and hands him a heavy sack.  Tremoille and Regnault are present, as always.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here... to help pay Jeanne's ransom. All the Captains gave what they could, as well as the citizens of Orleans and the other towns she saved...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Very generous of you all.  How much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10,000 gold crowns. From their expressions, this is clearly an enormous amount.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 10,000... that's a lot... but I fear not enough.  But it will be my pleasure to make up the difference. (to Archbishop Regnault)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your Grace... I place you in charge of this... sensitive negotiation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Burgundy's right-arm -- DIJON -- turns to his Assistant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They send a Bishop to negotiate? That's a good sign.  Let him in. It is not Archbishop Regnault who enters, but another ecclesiastic swaddled in the rich robes of his office: the Bishop of Beauvais, one Pierre CAUCHON.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good day, sir.  I trust my honorable Duke of Burgundy is feeling well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's feeling wonderful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks be to God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And your Duke?  The Duke of Bedford?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not so well, I regret to say.  This business with the Maiden... it's caused him endless grief and torment.  That's why he's entrusted me with the task of... shall we say...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buying her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This word is -- regrettably appropriate for the situation.  In fact what we -- the Church -- wish to do is determine whether or not this girl is sent by God, as she claims.  You understand that we cannot allow just anybody to abuse God's name in this manner...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand.  How much? It is that other man of the cloth, Regnault, who answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 5,000 gold crowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is all his majesty can afford. He has even donated his very own personal savings.  His majesty will greatly appreciate a gesture of good will in this delicate negotiation between our two families.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know... but the English want her very badly, and I have to tell you that they are proving much more generous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I, without offending you, inquire how generous?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 20,000 gold crowns. Regnault's rival cleric Cauchon looks aghast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 20,000?!  But... I heard King Charles was... financially embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't look at the cost, look at what it brings.  What is your last offer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 8,000.  We can't raise more... We can only place ourselves at the mercy of your generosity.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I must offer to the Duke.  I will give you his answer tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Burgundian Soldier shakes Jeanne to wake her up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, wake up... get yourself ready... you're leaving! Jeanne opens her eyes as Cauchon enters her cell, dressed in ecclesiastical robes.  He stands in front of her, flanked by two monks.  At the sigh of the churchmen, she brightens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, thank you Lord! (to Cauchon)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so glad to see you!  I need to confess... I haven't been confessed since Easter... or been to Mass... Will you hear me now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will hear you... but not now, not here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pierre Cauchon, Bishop of Beauvais. As you were captured in my diocese, the duty of conducting the trial falls upon me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trial?  What trial??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your trial, Jeanne.  On a charge of heresy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But... the King -- my king -- didn't he pay my ransom?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seems that the English care more about you than the French.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The English??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  They paid your ransom... tomorrow you will be transferred to their great castle at Rouen. The door slams shut, and she is left alone.  Jeanne is utterly distraught.  She looks round the bleak cell, then moves over to a small window... just wide enough for her to squeeze through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne clambers out onto a narrow ledge, high above the frozen moat below.  Only a fool -- or one bent on suicide -- would hazard such a leap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Need some help? The Man we saw after Compiegne is once again behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing out here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might ask you the same question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I'm leaving... I can't take anymore...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what exactly is it that you can't take anymore of?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everything!  Prison -- humiliation -- being abandoned and betrayed by everyone -- I can't stand it anymore -- I'd rather die!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll be dead soon enough anyway, so why be in such a hurry?  Why not face up to your lies?  It's your lies you can't stand anymore...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I never lied!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you were true to yourself... if your faith was firm, you wouldn't need to run away from yourself like this...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am true -- to my Lord, the King of Heaven.  He knows how much I love him -- that's all that matters to me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you pretend that you love God when you're about to throw away the most precious thing he gave you? Life is a gift, you should know that by now Jeanne -- a gift from God. You know what He'd say to you, if He was here?  "What are you doing to me, Jeanne?" Jeanne is lost, exhausted, numbed.  She gazes into the void, contemplating the fall...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right... I shouldn't do that. The Man suddenly pushes her so that she nearly falls...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
