dialogues.text: That's too easy.  One minute you want to die, the next you want to live... (again pushes her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think that life is a toy that can be played with and then broken when you don't want it anymore?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no... I'm just so tired, and lost, and... I didn't realize what I was doing! He pushes her again...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh?  And just because you realize now, everybody else should forgive you?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know -- I don't care anymore -- I just want to be at peace!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, so you don't want war anymore? You want to be at peace?  You want to be able to change your mind anytime you feel like it and expect everyone to go along with it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand.  What do you want from me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you already... I'm here to set you free... Again the Man pushes her!  This time she loses her balance, and with a startled cry falls from the ledge -- plunging down, down -- and crashing into the frozen moat...! Two castle GUARDS on watch are alerted by the SOUND of splintering ice... Jeanne is drowning, barely able to cling to the broken ic around her.  The first Guard to reach the moat tests the surface with his foot...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't try -- you'll fall through! The First Guard lies flat to spread his weight, then crawls toward Jeanne...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good God, it's the prisoner! The Second Guard glances up at the tower ledge far above...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If she jumped from up there, she's dead for sure!  forget it... The First Guard reaches the edge of the hole just as Jeanne disappears beneath the water.  He plunges in his hand and grabs her hair, pulling her head back above the water...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aulon races along castle corridors until he reaches a door, guarded by two burly Guards...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The king is occupied...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Out of my way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aulon bursts into the room to find Charles, Regnault and Tremoille in conversation...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear Aulon... (dismissing Guards)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's fine...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne's been badly injured!  She jumped from the top of a tower into a frozen moat! Charles shivers at the thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a miracle she's not dead!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have to do something before she tries it again!  I beg of you, my lord, don't let her down... let me organize an escape...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jean, it's... it's not so easy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But not impossible... Gilles and La Hire are ready to risk everything to save her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jean... me dear, loyal Jean... why do you want to oppose the will of God?  Jeanne wanted to go to Compiegne -- we let her -- she got caught.  Then, on my personal orders, Regnault proposed 30,000 crowns for her ransom, and once again the answer was no.  And now you say she tried to escape, and the answer is still no.  Jean, open your eyes -- can't you see the hand of God in all this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I see the hand of Tremoille, and Regnault, and Yolande, and you... and they are dirty hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you speak such treachery when his majesty has done everything to try and save her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I was at this door when you planned to betray her... and I was at Compiegne when she was betrayed. Charles, Tremoille and Regnault are speechless.  Tremoill breaks the silence --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guards!  Arrest this traitor! The Two Guards turn on Aulon, who readily dispatches them with his sword.  Tremoille hides behind Charles just as Aulon pins the King with the tip of his sword against his windpipe.  It would now be an easy matter for Tremoille t push Charles onto the tip of Aulon's sword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you fear most now... my sword? (eyeing Tremoille)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... or his hands?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tremoille... don't.  Please... Tremoille hesitates a beat.  Still holding the tip of his sword at Charles' throat, Aulon motions to Tremoille...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My sword is long enough for both of you. Sweating now, Tremoille eases himself from behind the King's back.  Charles exhales with relief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have always been loyal and true to you, but my allegiance is now at an end.  From now on, my loyalty belongs to Jeanne... ... and Aulon runs from the room, leaving Charles, Tremoille and Regnault in a state of shock.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aulon gallops away from the castle...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The great castle of Rouen, vast and bleak, silhouetted against the dusk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Guard leads a group of wealthy-looking visitors along a dank, dark corridor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... so don't say I didn't warn you! Don't touch her whatever you do -- don't even stretch out your hand or she'll have one of your fingers off sooner than spit at you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As savage as that, is she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Savage?  She's a monster!  At Orleans they say she drank her victim's blood!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, it's too horrible! The woman's escort takes advantage of the situation...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, my sweet -- I'll have my sword at the ready... They reach the door, and the Guard fumbles for the right key.  The Duke of Bedford brings up the rear, escorting his wife Anne, who is visibly pregnant...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you think this visit is a little... inappropriate?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My dear, it's our duty... she's our guest! The Guard unlocks the door, and the Group cautiously enter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The visitors glance about, but the cell appears empty -- until they look up.  An iron cage is hanging from the middle of the ceiling.  In the center of the cage is a body, dressed in rags and curled up like a wounded animal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wake her up so we can see her face! The Guard takes his cudgel and pokes her through the bars

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, wake up... we got noble guests -- don't disappoint them -- turn round! He prods her in the ribs, and she turns to avoid further pain.  Her face is swollen, her mouth parched, her eyes full of grief.  The Duchess is stunned...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now she's sleepy but you wait and see -- any moment now and she'll start speaking to her devils, and then she'll get to yelping like a wolf in heat!  The other night she made her cage spin round so fast we thought she was going to fly away!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oooo... she gives me creeps...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want her to stand up so you can get a better look?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  But get her out of this cage and give her a decent bed. The Guard looks stunned.  The Duchess turns to her husband.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, but this child is being treated like an animal!  Don't you think that whatever her crimes may be, she deserves a little more of our charity?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (whispering lightly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's not a child, my dear -- she's a witch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cauchon enters a large, gloomy courtroom and sits down, surrounded by clerics, assessors, doctors of theology and other churchmen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let the prisoner be brought in. The door opens and Jeanne is led in, her wrists and ankle fettered, her face pale and drawn.  She stands in the center of the room, isolated, alone.  A scribe dips his quill in the ink and prepares to write on a blank sheet o parchment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our most serene and Christian King Henry the Sixth, King of England and France, has handed this girl over to us, accused of a number of heretical deeds, to be tried in a matter of faith. Jeanne is hustled closer to Cauchon, who leans forward, peering at her intently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take the Holy Gospels in your hand and swear to tell the whole truth concerning everything you will be asked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you're going to ask me questions about.  You may ask things that I won't want to answer. Jeanne's boldness takes everyone somewhat by surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will swear to tell the truth about whatever you are asked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will willingly swear to tell the truth about earthly things, but as for my revelations, I've never told anyone except my king... Charles the Seventh... the one and only king of France. There is murmured dissension among the judges.  We now se that the Duke of Bedford is also in the room, together with a small coterie of English observers.  Cauchon is impatient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must take the oath!  Not even a king, would refuse to take an oath to tell the truth in a matter of faith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will willingly swear to tell you what I am allowed to tell you, but as to the rest, even if you threaten to cut off my head, I still won't tell you. Cauchon looks confused -- and aware that his authority is slipping.  The judges and theologians are getting agitated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... begin by telling us your name -- assuming you're allowed to tell us that much?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Jeanne.  My little cross I had round my neck was taken away from me.  I would like to have it back. The Duchess touches the gold cross she has around her neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Show us a little more cooperation first.  Where were you born?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a village called Domremy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How old are you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nineteen... or thereabouts...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you baptized?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  In the church at Domremy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Recite the Lord's Prayer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not unless you hear my confession. Cauchon is getting impatient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne, listen to me very carefully. We are all men of faith, and we shall earnestly strive for the salvation of both your soul and body as though it were our own.  We do so in the name of our Holy Mother Church, who never closes her arms to those who would return to her.  But we cannot help you unless you submit to our learned judgment and authority.  Take heed of this charitable admonition, for if you persist in refusing our help, then we shall have no choice but to abandon you to the secular powers, and I think you know well enough the punishment that would await you.  So now... will you please recite Our Lord's Prayer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not unless you hear my confession. The clerks and judges grow agitated, though we sense a fe are already beginning to warm to her, not least the Duchess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne -- be careful -- you're not helping yourself by refusing to submit to our judgment...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you be careful, you who claim to be my judges, for you too will be judged one day...! The court explodes in protest, with cries of "Blasphemy!" "She's possessed!"  "An infected limb!"  "Sorceress!" Cauchon hammers on the table to restore order, calling out --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guards!  Take the prisoner away! Clear the room! Armed Guards hustle the clerics from the room while Jeann is led away, watched by the Duke and Duchess of Bedford.. Bedford turns to his aide (Buck) --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I count on you to have it done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh... to have what done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want her burned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you say, sir.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The assessors look extremely uncomfortable, not least Pierre Cauchon, who does his best to conceal it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... in the future I think we should conduct our enquiries in private -- away from public pressure -- so we can all be more... level- headed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think the church should wash its hands of this whole business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let the English burn her if they want to... why does it have to involve us? Buck enters the room as an old Priest walks over...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it's... it's our clear duty to root out heresy wherever it occurs. (to the Old Priest)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Father Vincente... you are the most venerable among us, what do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think this trial is a masquerade, and I won't be part of it anymore. I am willing to be her judge, but not her executioner.  This young girl seems courageous and pious... she deserves to be well judged. The Old Priest walks toward the door...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I'm trying to ensure!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The verdict comes at the end of a trial, Cauchon, not at the beginning.  I am going back to Rome, to give me report to our Holy Father the Pope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is ridiculous!  Now I'm the one who's on trial and being judged?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... exactly as Jeanne predicted. The Old Priest heads for the door, followed by the other two.  Buck calls out to the Guards...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Arrest them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?  This is an ecclesiastical court -- you have no right to do this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rouen is in English territory.  I have the right to do anything I like. (to guards)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take them away. Ignoring their protestations, the Guards hustle them away leaving the others in a state of high anxiety.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne is in her cell, facing the wall and frantically scratching it with her nails.  She is engraving a cross, and her nails are covered with blood... She is now kneeling in front of her cross, racing through The Lord's Prayer as though on the run from the Devil...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our father who is in heaven hallowed be thy name thy kingdom come in earth as it is in heaven forgive them that lead... forgive us that lead them... as we forgive them that... oh God, don't cut yourself off from me like this... I don't know what I'm meant to say or not say anymore... I don't even know what to think... oh, God, I'm so lost... don't abandon me like everyone else... please, I beg of you... at least say you can hear me...!  Tell me you hear me...!  Why won't you answer me?  Please, I beg of you -- ANSWER ME! Suddenly "the Man" comes out of the wall, kneeling in front of her and violently hitting his forehead against hers --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why were you yelling like that?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing here? (urgently)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please... leave... you can't stay here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?  Are you waiting for someone else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who? Jeanne hesitates...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My... visions...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're going to come and visit you in here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... that's what I pray for...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to see that.  Do you mind if I stay... on the side?  I won't bother you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no -- you can't stay or they won't come!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because... I have to be alone! He smiles regretfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They won't come anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean, they won't come?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because!  Because I've always been faithful to God, and I've followed everything he said... and I've done everything he asked me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God asked you to do something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... lots of things!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean God said, "I need you, Jeanne?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but... he sent me so many signs!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What signs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like... like the wind... and the clouds... and... the bells... and what about that sword lying in the field... that was a sign...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  That was a sword in a field.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But... it didn't just get there by itself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: True -- every event has an infinite number of causes -- but why pick one rather than another?  There are many ways a sword might find itself in a field... FLASH:  A group of soldiers on horseback trot across the field of Jeanne's childhood.  The last soldier's sword is coming loose, and ends up falling into the long grass...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seems a perfectly valid explanation... but how about this one... FLASH:  Two young children are hurrying with the sword when an old man calls them from far away --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you little devils -- come back! The two children drop the sword in the long grass (in the same spot as before) and run off...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But then again, there are other possibilities... FLASH:  A man is being chased across the field by a coupl of English soldiers out looting.  His heavy sword is slowing him down -- he flings it into the long grass...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... or even faster... FLASH:  The same man running across the field is suddenly hit by an arrow from nowhere.  He drops the sword in the long grass, but manages to stagger off into the forest...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and that's without counting the inexplicable... FLASH:  A man crosses the field.  For no apparent reason whatsoever, he drops the sword and keeps on walking...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yet from an infinite number of possibilities, you had to pick this one... FLASH:  A peel of thunder -- clouds swirl -- a familiar wind stirs the long grass -- a fabulous shaft of light illuminates the patch -- the sword slowly descends from the heavens and lands gently in the grass.  Mission accomplished, the shaft of heavenly light disappears. Jeanne is bewildered...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't see what was, Jeanne. You saw what you wanted to see. ... speechless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are now in a smaller, more intimate courtroom.  The Duchess of Bedford is at the back, shielded behind the theologians and doctors of the church.  Beaupere is questioning Jeanne:  a cooler man than Cauchon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This... "voice" that you say appears to you... is it an angel?  Or a saint?  Or does it come from God? Jeanne is still in shock from her encounter with the Man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't tell you more about that. I'm more afraid of displeasing Him than not answering you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're afraid of displeasing God when telling the truth?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did God forbid you to tell the truth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  But my revelations were for the King of France, not for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you saw your king for the first time, was there an angel over his head?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there was, I didn't see it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then why did your king believe in you without any proof?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go and ask him yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne, you are not helping yourself.  If you don't answer our questions properly, your refusal will be taken into account.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These questions have nothing to do with your trial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I assure you they do.  So... answer me... when was the last time you heard this voice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not long ago...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When exactly?  A day, a week -- when?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Last night. This takes the assessors by surprise.  Cauchon leans forward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What were you doing when the voice came?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Praying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The voice was in your cell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did it tell you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Many things...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did it give you advice? (Jeanne hesitates)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good advice? Jeanne hesitates...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go onto the next question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good advice for the French, not for the English!  Do you think God hates the English?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, but you're all men of the church... why not ask Him yourself? Cauchon tries to continue, but another theologian -- JEAN MIDI -- gets in first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you consider yourself to be in a state of grace? Jeanne looks perplexed... a beat...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on to the next question. Cauchon seizes his opportunity...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell us, Jeanne... do you often hear this voice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it here?  Now?  In this room? Jeanne slowly looks at the assessors, staring at each in turn.  They all look acutely uneasy, holding there breath...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Relief from the assessors, but Buck is far from happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buck paces in front of Cauchon and a dozen clerics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's running this trial, you or her?  I can't believe it!  This wretched girl -- how dare she speak to us like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's loyal to her king... it's only to be expected that she... Buck explodes with fury --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is only one king of France and that's our liege Lord Henry the Sixth!  It is written in black and white in the Treaty of Troyes -- that you French bastards signed! Buck presses a digit against Cauchon's sweaty forehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand your impatience, but if you want this trial to be acknowledged as legal we must follow correct procedure and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To hell with procedure!  We paid a bloody fortune for this slut, and we can do whatever the hell we like with her, whether the church likes it or not -- is that clear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if this trial seems fixed, I fear you'll have the very opposite result to the one you want...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We want her burned as a witch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But in order to do so, the church must first prove her heresy, or else you'll be burning a martyr...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then?  Start proving... or else the church will have another martyr! Buck storms out, slamming the door behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Instruments of torture are brought into court by the Executioner, who lays them out with due ceremony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You told us about the appearance of this... voice.  What exactly did you see?  Part of it... or all of it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does he have hair?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it long and hanging down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm more interested in what he says, not what he looks like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if the devil were to take on the physical appearance of a saint or an angel... or a man... how would you recognize him?  By what he said?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on to the next question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's enough!  You will answer the question... or face the consequences! A beat... the Executioner readies...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you were to tear me limb from limb and make my soul leave my body, I would tell you nothing more.  And if I did say anything, then afterward I would simply say that you dragged it out of me by force. Now... please... go onto the next question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUT TO another session...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who told you to wear men's clothes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The clothes are not important...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You also cut your hair short like a man, and in the Bible it clearly states that it is an abomination for a woman to pretend to be a man!  It proves your desire to deceive...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was just... more convenient as I was among soldiers...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you think you did well to cut your hair and dress as a man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... submit to Our Lord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But will you also submit to the decision of the Church?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seems to me that the Church and Our Lord are one and the same.  Why must you complicate what is so simple? Jean Le Maistre looks at Cauchon for help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me clarify things for you, Jeanne.  On the one hand there is the Church Triumphant, that is to say God, his saints, and the souls that are saved.  And then there is the Church Militant, that is to say our Holy Father the Pope, the cardinals, the prelates of the Church, the clergy, and all good Catholic Christians.  Moreover this Church, when assembled, is guided by the Holy Spirit and therefore cannot be in error.  That is why we ask you to submit to the Church Militant... that is to say, us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it is the Church Militant that refuses to confess me, and so prevents me from being a good Christian? Cauchon bridles his temper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is for us to determine whether you are a good Christian, not you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am sent by God, and I submit all my words and deeds to His judgment. Or do you think that you are better judges than He is?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and another session...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When you were taken prisoner at Compiegne, did you have a horse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... a half-steed... white.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who gave you that horse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My king.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many did he give you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five steeds and a few hackneys...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As much as for a Lord?  What an honor!  Did your king give you other wealth apart from horses?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about all those dresses you were given... silk dresses weren't they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I was given a few, but I never had time to wear them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still, pretty wealthy for a peasant girl wouldn't you say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you look pretty wealthy for a servant of God, wouldn't you say? Maitre Maurice looks uncomfortably about him.  She's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it true that you launched an attack on Paris?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I tried to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was on a Sunday, wasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't remember.  Maybe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think is was a good idea to launch an attack on a holy day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And didn't you order the citizens of Paris to surrender the city in the name of the King of Heaven?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... I said "Surrender in the name of the King of France"...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is not what is written in the evidence... look for yourself! Beaupere thrusts a document in her face...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, yes, I forgot... God sent us an illiterate peasant to carry out such an important mission!  Do you think that God made the right decision, to take an ignorant girl to save the kingdom of France?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I leave the answer to God. Beaupere is exasperated.  A sly-looking Theologian speaks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell us, Jeanne... why did you jump from the tower at Beaurevoir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had been sold to the English.  I'd rather die than fall into their hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did your voice tell you to jump?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So when you jumped, you wanted to kill yourself?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you deny it when you just said "I'd rather die than fall into the hands of the English"...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's now what I meant...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you not know that suicide is a very grievous sin?  No one is allowed to destroy the life that God created!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, but that's not the way things happened...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean it was not of your own free will that you were on the ledge?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you didn't jump of your free will?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (making fun of her)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh?  Perhaps someone pushed you then? They laugh.  Jeanne lowers her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yet another weary session...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a sword?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quite a few.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you also carry a banner?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which did you prefer, your banner or your sword?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was forty times more fond of my banner than my sword.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And why was that?  Did it have some particular value or power?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's just... a sword is a weapon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so I... I prefer my banner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To avoid killing anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you saying that if you had not been carrying your banner you'd have killed more people? Jeanne is losing her confidence...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, of course not... I never killed anyone...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then perhaps the temptation to kill would have been stronger... too strong perhaps...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!  I warned the English to go back home -- I begged them not to force us to fight -- they knew the defeat I would bring on them... why didn't they listen to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We have numerous witnesses who can confirm that you were not always carrying your banner...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, probably... maybe...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So sometimes you were carrying just your sword?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you use the sword that you held in your hand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I... I held it up to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You held up your sword and flourished it about in the air? Like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, maybe... I don't remember...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... so you were in the middle of the battlefield, with your sword in your hand, waving it above your head... charging against the enemy, screaming and yelling... fighting for your life... and you want us to believe that in the middle of all this excitement you never killed anyone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I... I never killed anyone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe you can lie like that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne's fetter is once again attached to her chain, and she's walking in circles, trying to escape "the Man"...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not lying, I... I can't remember... leave me alone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh?  You can't remember?  Let me help your memory... FLASH:  an Englishman is skewed during the battle of Orleans...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!  I don't want to know anymore! Leave me alone!  I didn't kill that man!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no?  How about this one? FLASH:  another English soldier is killed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or this one? FLASH:  ... and another...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop, stop... I can't remember!  The battles were all so confusing... there was so much smoke, dust, noise... I was being attacked on all sides, so... maybe... perhaps I fought back but it was only to defend myself...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So your memory's coming back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... yes!  And now you tell me why God let all these battles happen in the first place... if he's so powerful... he said he's "the creator of heaven and earth, the source of all life..." he could have easily stopped all this blood and misery?  Why didn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is he the one who spread all this blood and misery?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but... why didn't he stop it? Or did he get pleasure, watching us killing each other in his name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In His name??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!  We fought and killed in His name... the King of Heaven!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? FLASH:  Jeanne is seated in her saddle before Orleans, raising her standard with the cry --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let all who love me follow me! Back in Jeanne's cell:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Let all who love me follow me"... Where does God get mentioned? (Jeanne is cornered)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on Jeanne, be honest.  You fought for yourself, in your name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I... I was defending myself as best I could!  Everyone has the right to defend themselves, don't they?  Or should I have let myself be killed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, you did fine.  I'd even say well done.  Besides, most of the ones you killed probably deserved it, don't you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I do not think so.  I don't think that killing each other will ever bring peace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I agree... FLASHBACK:  Jeanne telling Charles --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peace will only be got from the English at the end of a lance! The Man looks at Jeanne, who is becoming unnerved...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't agree.  Why do you have to keep changing your mind all the time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you doing this to me??  Do you get pleasure from hurting me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, pleasure... that's a difficult word to define.  When does the pain end and the pleasure begin...? When did your pleasure begin with that sword in your hand...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never took pleasure in hurting anyone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? FLASH:  In EXTREME SLOW MOTION, Jeanne's face contorts -- a look of madness as she sweeps a sword across the SCREEN...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nnnnooooooooo! Jeanne covers her face with her hands, sobbing in despair

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Help me... please... set me free! The Man seems genuinely compassionate...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will be, Jeanne.  You will be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hooded Priest moves along the hallway, stopping in fron of the Guard.  He shows him his "pass" -- a heavy seal. The Priest is Aulon in disguise.  The Guard looks at the seal...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm replacing Father Demaury.  He's become very sick...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's amazing how many people have become suddenly very sick since the beginning of this trial... it must be this witch casting spells on them.  Burn her! No doubt Aulon would like to stab the Guard right there, but thinks better of it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll do my best. Aulon enters the court room...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- and sits on a bench, doing his best to look inconspicuous.  He guardedly glances at Jeanne who seems to be asleep on her feet.  Beaupere is whispering to Cauchon, document in hand.  Beaupere beckons to the Guard...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wake her up. The Guard pokes Jeanne in the ribs.  She seems almost use to this kind of treatment, but is weaker.  Aulon seethes with impotent rage, hidden behind his hood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So... let us summarize your situation.  You refuse to submit to the authority of the church militant by taking an oath; you made an assault on Paris on a Sunday; you hurled yourself down from the tower at Beaurevoir, and you persist in wearing male dress... I ask you again:  do you believe that you are in a state of grace? Jeanne takes a deep breath...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I am not, may God bring me there. If I am, may He keep me there. The admiration of the assessors is almost tangible.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Buck sweeps everything off the table in a fit of anger. Alone with him, Cauchon looks troubled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Calm down, my lord, I beg you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can I calm down when I'm made the laughing-stock of the whole court?!  I've had enough!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be patient, my lord... you've seen how it is.  This girl has a way with people... but everyday we're making progress...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So long as this bitch remains alive, our armies refuse to fight!  Don't you understand?  They want proof that God is on their side... and the only way they're going to believe that is when they see her being burnt as a witch! Buck takes a mug and pours himself some wine, but the carafe is empty...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is not for us to burn her, my lord.  That is your prerogative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and your prerogative is to find her guilty...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we can't do that unless she admits to blasphemy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well what are you waiting for? You've got a castle full of racks and ropes and pulleys:  go and torture the bitch! Cauchon takes out his own personal hip-flask, his hand visibly trembling as he pours Buck some liquor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You won't be able to drag anything from her that way.  You also must realize that many of my colleagues are... well, scared...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scared of a girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scared to make a mistake.  Supposing she's right... supposing she really has been sent by God?? Buck narrows his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose side are you on, Cauchon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm on the side of our Mother Holy Church.  Besides, a confession under torture will never convince anyone of her guilt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well find some other way!  Be creative.  Tell them she fucks the devil... Hmm, not a bad idea... why can't you say that?  Sounds good to me... and who can prove she doesn't? Buck drains the liquor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One small problem, my lord.  The girl is a virgin. Buck has a horrible glint in his eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is a very small problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne is smoothing food into the cross she scratched int the wall.  She does it with great care, as though painting.  The Man appears in the background, watching her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing? Jeanne is delighted and relieved to see him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I -- I cleaned up my room, look... and I said my prayers... all of them... and...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing on the wall?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to make my cross look more beautiful...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because... because I don't know what else to do to please him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think this cross will protect you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I... Jeanne looks helpless.  The Man smiles, turns and looks out of the window...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at them... with their beautiful cross... Far below in the courtyard, a Priest is blessing a dozen soldiers and their wooden cross.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... The sight of priests blessing entire armies before they go off to kill each other never ceases to amaze me.  And that these massacres should be recorded as acts of faith in God's name... (no reaction from Jeanne)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And they think that making a beautiful cross or building a cathedral will wash away their sins... ridiculous!  Just like that priest who accused you of fighting on a Sunday.  Did God give permission to kill each other for the rest of the week? In the courtyard, the soldiers mount their horses...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Love your enemies"...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a satisfied smile)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  But "love your enemies"... body and soul. Jeanne nods, knowing the truth but still not prepared to admit it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My voices... my voices... do you think they will ever come back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think so.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you going to leave me too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes... of course... when you don't need me anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sent by God? FLASH:  to Jeanne at Orleans...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you've been sent by God!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So has everyone... Back to the Man:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So has everyone... Jeanne looks at him -- then at her cross -- then back at the soldiers in the courtyard below.  With a lusty cry, they set off at a gallop, blessed and ready for battle...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing for me to do here anymore... I don't belong here I want to be with Him now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think you are ready? Jeanne stands up... comes and kneels before him, kissing his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you willing to follow all His commandments?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... to love your enemy as much as you love yourself? Jeanne hesitates a moment -- a short amount of time, but enough for a lie to slip in...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  I'm ready now. The Man smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see. She hears approaching footsteps... the SOUND of keys jangling... a lock turns -- -- and the three SOLDIERS walk into the room.  The first one has a familiar black beard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now that's what I call booty! He is none other than her sister's rapist and murderer. Jeanne reacts in terror...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (undoing his belt)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We thought you must be pretty bored in here, so we've come to liven you up a bit... right, lads?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please -- don't do it -- don't hurt me --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not, sweetheart... if you promise to do as I say... Blackbeard caresses her cheek and tries to force her legs apart, but she resists -- whispers imploringly...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you?  Don't leave me... please...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, come on... open up...! His two comrades egg him on.  Jeanne struggles even harder, and Blackbeard suddenly becomes violent.  He grab her by the throat, thrusts her against the bed and tears off her clothes.  Jeanne suddenly goes berserk, yelling and thrashing like a cornered animal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop screaming like that!  You'll wake up the whole bleedin' castle! Blackbeard clamps his hand over her mouth, whereupon Jeanne summons hidden reserves of strength, and in a sudden surge manages to clamp her chains around Blackbeard's neck... she presses down on the chains, choking him, strangling him...! The two other soldiers come to Blackbeard's rescue and manage to haul her off.  Blackbeard gropes his throat, then belts her across the face...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, so you want to play it rough? Good... I like it better that way! He pulls out a knife and starts to tear at her clothes while the two others hold her down.  Jeanne struggles for her life -- yelling, spitting, biting, scratching -- Blackbeard is too excited to pay any attention.  Nor does he notice the door open and the Duchess enter with the Guard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop that at once!  That's an order! But to Blackbeard, it could be Jeanne speaking.  The Duchess, in her nightgown, grabs Blackbeard by the shoulders...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I command you to stop, in the name of the King! The mention of the King jolts Blackbeard to attention...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Leave her alone, do you hear?  Come on, get out! The three soldiers back sheepishly away...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were just having a little fun, that's all, keeping her company.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men like you are the cause of our country's dishonor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were serving our country... just obeying orders, ma'am... The Duchess doesn't want to hear more...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, get out of here! The Guards hustle the three soldiers from the room, but not before Blackbeard has mumbled --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you later, angel. The soldiers leave and the Guard bolts the door behind them.  Jeanne curls up on her bed, destroyed, humiliated, lost.  The Duchess caresses her face and doesn't know wha to do to comfort her.  The Guard brings a blanket -- probably his.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you... She wraps the blanket round Jeanne, and presses the littl cross back in her hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This won't happen again, I give you my word.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Duchess storms into a room where Cauchon is talking with Bedford and Buck.  She walks up to him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And... What a pleasant surprise... ... and slaps him across the face as he has never been slapped before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should know that each humiliation you inflict on this woman, you inflict on all women, including yours my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wha... what on earth are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you send anymore of your soldiers to Jeanne's cell... I will kill them myself. The Duchess turns and sweeps past Cauchon, leaving Bedfor staring at Buck who looks decidedly embarrassed.  Bedford turns to Cauchon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm giving you one more day. Then he turns and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A masked Executioner stands beside a stake, piled high with faggots.  Jeanne, her hands bound, stands nearby, facing a podium filled with the usual assembly of priests and prelates, headed by Cauchon.  He rises to address Jeanne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne, my very dear friend in Christ, we, your judges and assessors, desirous of reaching a true and lawful verdict, submitted a transcript of your trial to the University of Paris in order to obtain their opinion.  After careful consideration, the learned scholars have concluded with us that you have committed many grievous sins, and I ask you to listen most carefully to their opinion as contained in these articles. Cauchon hands a manuscript to one of the assessors, Canon Pierre Maurice, then resumes his seat.  Among the monks w spot Aulon, who slowly tries to make his way toward Jeanne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Article One.  You have said that from an early age you have had revelations from the blessed saints and angels, that you have seen them with your own eyes, and that they speak to you.  As to this article, the learned scholars have declared that these claims are untrue, pernicious and evil, and that all such revelations are superstitious, and proceed from the devil. The Duke of Bedford and his English peers are in a separate stand, guarded by English soldiers.  The cemeter walls and the branches of trees beyond are crowded with spectators... The English are impatient to carry out sentence, but Maurice is not a man to be intimidated.  Jeanne seems hardly aware of what is being said...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Article Two.  You said that by God's command you have continually worn men's clothes, and that you have also worn your hair short, without nothing... From Jeanne's POV, Maurice's drone FADES, and the crowd seems to disappear.  She whispers in agony...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lord... don't abandon me... where are you?  Is this what you want? You want me to burn?  To burn without being confessed...?  I'll do anything you want... but don't leave me... Jeanne is completely alone in the middle of the cemetery. Only the graves, the stakes, and the moaning wind...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't leave me here... please... don't leave me alone! Suddenly the crowd is back, with Maurice droning on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Finally, Article Twelve.  You have said that you are not willing to submit yourself to the judgment of the Church Militant, but only to God.  As to this Article, the scholars say that you have no comprehension of the authority of the Church, that you have perniciously erred in the faith of God, and that you are a child of superstition, a wanderer from the Faith, an invoker of demons, a sorceress, an idolater and a heretic! Maurice resumes his seat while Chatillon approaches Jeanne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne, we once again admonish, beg and exhort you to cast out and recant your erroneous beliefs, and return into the way of truth by submitting yourself to the authority of our Mother Holy Church by signing this recantation. Jeanne looks at the parchment in confusion...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If the church wants me to say that my visions are evil, then I don't believe in this church and I submit myself to the judgment of God! Chatillon throws up his hands in despair.  Bedford is brimming with anticipation.  He calls out to the Executioner:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perform your office! The Executioner turns to Jeanne, but before he can take hold of her, Cauchon strides over --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait!    Cauchon grabs the document from Chatillon and holds it up to Jeanne...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne, I beg of you... sign! (Jeanne looks dazed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In God's name, don't you understand? I'm trying to save you!  If you don't sign, the English will burn you to death!  Is that what you want??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... I want to be confessed. Cauchon hands her a quill.  The English are getting agitated, heckling Cauchon to hand her over, but the spectators in the trees and on the wall are urging her escape the pyre by signing.  Jeanne begins to waver...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sign this, and I will confess you myself if you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And may I go to Mass?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As often as you like -- now, please -- for the love of God -- sign!! Again Jeanne looks about for the Man... but sees only the Executioner, waiting to conduct her to the stake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sign, and you'll be free from your chains... free from the fire, Jeanne... now... sign! The Crowd begins to chant... Sign, sign, sign!  Aulon, wh has managed to get closer, joins them...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sign, Jeanne -- sign! Bedford is in a panic as Jeanne takes the quill and makes her mark -- a wavering cross at the bottom of the parchment.  The Crowd cheers, Aulon is ecstatic... but their voices go silent as the Man once again appears from behind Cauchon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what you just signed, Jeanne?  You just signed away my existence... For you I'm a lie, an illusion. (Jeanne is horrified)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see?  In the end, you were the one who abandoned me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No... ... the Man a smile of faint regret and disappears. Jeanne turns to Cauchon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please... may I have it back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have nothing to regret... She tries to grab it from Cauchon, but soldiers pinion her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean it!  I didn't know what I was signing!  You tricked me...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence her! (soldier clamps hand over her mouth)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take her away...! The Soldiers hustle her away as Cauchon walks back to the podium.  Aulon is relieved, and yet strangely apprehensive.  Cauchon hands the Duke the document signed by Jeanne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There... she has recanted, and we accept her repentance, for the church never closes her arms to those who return to the fold.  She's yours to do whatever you want with her, but the church has nothing to do with it anymore.  She's your prisoner -- your martyr -- not ours. Bedford can't answer as the Duchess is next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne is flung into a filthy dungeon.  Buck appears in the doorway and flings male clothes in her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here... in case you want to get dressed -- try these for size!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He promised I'd be confessed... and go to Mass... and be free from these chains...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We never promised you anything!  But this much I can promise you... that you won't be leaving this dungeon till the day you die! The Guards laugh, slamming and bolting the door behind her.  Jeanne sinks to her knees in grief and anguish...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dawn is breaking beyond the distant castle...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cauchon is alone, lost in his thoughts.  A young monk run in, out of breath...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My lord Bishop... come quickly...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cauchon and the Monk hurry across the castle courtyard. Aulon sees them pass, anxious at their apparent concern..

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cauchon arrives in Jeanne's dungeon, out of breath.  It i full of people:  Bedford, his Aide, priests and soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, Cauchon... come to see for yourself?  Well, take a look. Beyond them stands Jeanne, her back to us, dressed as a man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see?  Dressed as a man again! Her touching repentance didn't last very long, did it.  The Bishop of Senlis was passing by and was on hand to witness her very evident relapse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And by what miracle did these clothes find their way in here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a miracle, my dear Cauchon... an evil spell!  This girl is a witch, and tomorrow she will burn for it! (to Buck)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have the stake prepared in the market place...! Jeanne doesn't say a word.  She stands with her back to us, gazing up at the dim crack of light bleeding in through the high window-slit.  Bedford exits with the others, leaving Cauchon alone with Jeanne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand, Jeanne... why did you do it?  Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you?  Why did you lie?  You promised I could be confessed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know, Jeanne... it was the only way to save you from the fire!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not my body I want to save. It's my soul. Jeanne turns round, and we see that she is strangely calm as though a great weight had been lifted from her.  She kneels before Cauchon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I ask only one thing... to hear me in confession...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I -- I can't Jeanne... I can't hear your confession... I'm sorry... He hurries out of the cell.  A Guard locks the door behin him, and Jeanne is alone.  But not for long.  The Man materializes and sits next to her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you really want to confess, Jeanne? (Jeanne nods)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm listening. He turns his back, as the Priest did in the confessional.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have committed sins, my Lord -- so many sins.  As a child, the only way I could help my people was to pray. So I prayed to God and his saints. I prayed more and more, and gave God all my love... but isn't it said that God helps them who help themselves?  So I helped myself... and I saw signs... the ones I wanted to see -- and I fought, out of revenge and despair.  Yes, I was proud -- stubborn -- selfish -- and cruel... I was all the things that humans believe they are allowed to be when they're fighting for a cause. The Man smiles a little, satisfied sigh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think you are ready now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, my lord.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see. As he disappears, she hears a noise... turns round and sees a Guard in the doorway... A beat, then the Guard topples forward to the floor, bloo oozing from his mouth.  Behind him stands a Priest.  He pulls a sword from the Guard's body, then throws back his hood.  It is Aulon.  He runs to Jeanne and takes her in his arms...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne... thank God! He quickly sets about removing her chains from her ankle...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We must hurry -- I took care of the guard, but others are coming...! Jeanne gently caresses his hand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am ready now...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just give me a moment and then you'll be free...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm already free...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (preoccupied)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes yes... any moment... you're always so impatient... Jeanne puts her hand on his to stop him wasting his time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My gentle Captain... I'm staying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I -- I don't understand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One day you will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't know what you're saying. You're going to leave this place, Jeanne -- you're going home -- or whatever you want -- you're going to be happy, and have children, and... She caresses his face with both hands, smiling at him gently.  Aulon continues to talk, but his eyes are beginning to brim with tears... he knows it's useless, that Jeanne has made her decision...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and maybe the king will give you some money, and a little land, and a title even... (smiling through his tears)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... wouldn't that be a fine thing? You, a lady of title!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm staying, Jean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you must come, Jeanne -- we need you -- so much has happened since you left... I have a new horse now, a white one, just like yours... and La Hire hardly swears at all anymore... (crying)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't stay -- they'll burn you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not afraid of the fire anymore. It will purify me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeanne, you can't leave us like this! Jeanne smiles at him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am at peace now, my gentle friend... at peace with myself. She speaks gently, but with resolution:  there is no goin back, and Aulon knows it.  He hears the distant SOUND of soldiers approaching... Aulon takes Jeanne's face in his hands and kisses her on the lips.  A full kiss, the only one and the last one, on which Jeanne neither encourages nor resists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must go. She says it gently but urgently.  With tears welling, Aulon tears himself from her sight and disappears.  Jeann is left alone, strangely calm and serene.  Slowly she raises her finger-tips to her lips... touches them softly... The Man emerges from the darkness, carrying an ornate Cross on a long pole, bearing an effigy of the crucified Christ.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ego te absolvo, in nomine Patris, et Filii, et Spiritus Sancti, Amen... He stands in front of her, raising the Cross above...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ROUEN MARKET PLACE
dialogues.text: ... Jeanne, who looks up to see the crucifix rising against a clear blue sky, now held aloft by a Priest.  Sh is bound to the stake, her head shaved.  At the base of the pyre, the EXECUTIONER sprinkles the faggots with oil...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry, it's going to be fast... I used plenty of dry wood so there'll be lots of smoke... but don't forget to breath fast and you'll be dizzy before the flames even get to you... A great CROWD has assembled in the market place.  On a podium is the Duke of Bedford, trying to remain impassive Beside him, the Duchess can barely contain her emotions. Further along stands Cauchon, his eyes lowered, not wanting to see. Still disguised as a monk, Aulon stands close to the pyre tormented and torn between revenge and despair... Bedford makes a sign to the Executioner, who then takes a torch and sets fire to the brushwood.  Flames erupt, and Jeanne's breathing quickens.  As thick smoke rises, the Priest begins to cough; his eyes water, and he can no longer hold up the cross to Jeanne's sight.  She begins t panic, her eyes wildly searching...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... the... cross... show me the cross... please... The Priest struggles to hold it up, but the choking smoke drives him back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where... where are you...? Jeanne is filled with panic... the Priest is bent double with coughing and can get no closer...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... please... the cross! Suddenly Aulon rushes forward, grabs the cross from the Priest and boldly defies the smoke and flames, risking hi life as he holds it high for Jeanne... Finally the cross is visible to her, rising above the flames into a clear blue sky.  Her anxiety melts, her eye fill with tears of hope as she gazes up at the cross... As her eyes close, the image of the cross becomes engulfe with flames... until the smoke finally fills the SCREEN, plunging it into darkness...
